{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Globalize|date=June 2017}} '''Amazon tax''' collection policy has changed over the years. In the U.S., [[Sales taxes in the United States|state and local sales taxes]] are levied by state and local governments, not at the federal level. In most countries where Amazon operates, a sales tax or [[value added tax]] is uniform throughout the country, and Amazon is obliged to collect it from all customers.
Many U.S. states have passed [[online shopping]] sales tax laws designed to compel [[Amazon.com]] and other [[e-commerce]] retailers to collect state and local sales taxes from its customers. Amazon.com originally collected sales tax only from five states as of 2011, but as of April 2017 collects sales taxes from customers in all 45 states that have a state sales tax and in [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref name="Tax">{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/3/24/15055662/amazon-us-sales-tax-collection-all-states |title=Amazon will start collecting sales tax nationwide starting April 1st|publisher= The Verge|accessdate=April 6, 2017}}</ref> Amazon does not collect sales taxes from [[Alaska]], [[Delaware]], [[Montana]], [[New Hampshire]], and [[Oregon]], since those states do not have state sales taxes. Additionally, approximately half of all Amazon.com purchases are sold on the [[Amazon Marketplace]] through 3rd-party vendors, and these purchases remain free of tax except for in [[Washington state]], where these purchases (starting in 2018) are now taxed.<ref name="Taxes Everywhere">{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/03/29/technology/amazon-sales-tax/index.html|title=Amazon to start collecting state sales taxes everywhere|publisher=CNN Money|accessdate=July 25, 2017}}</ref><ref>https://www.cnbc.com/2017/11/15/amazon-marketplace-tax-collection-comes-to-washington-in-2018.html</ref>
==Background==
Proponents of forcing Amazon.com to collect sales tax—at least in states where it maintains a physical presence—argue the corporation wields an anti-competitive advantage over storefront businesses forced to collect sales tax.<ref name="Bloomberg/BusinessWeek">{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/smallbiz/content/apr2011/sb20110428_074924.htm|title=To Help Main Street, Close the Internet Sales Tax Loophole|last=Milchen|first=Jeff|date=28 April 2011|accessdate=17 November 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315102652/http://www.businessweek.com/smallbiz/content/apr2011/sb20110428_074924.htm|archivedate=15 March 2016}}</ref> Tax opponents respond to this argument by pointing out that individual states could make storefront businesses more competitive by lowering or entirely eliminating sales tax. Amazon is under increasing legal and political pressure from state governments, traditional retailers and other groups because of its refusal to collect sales tax in 41 of the 45 states with a statewide sales tax (as of March 2017). Those states include several where Amazon has a clear physical presence<ref name="amiba">{{cite web|url=http://www.amiba.net/resources/news-archive/amazon-nexus-subsidiaries|title=Amazon's Physical Presence (Nexus) in States and the Sales Tax Battle|publisher=[[American Independent Business Alliance]]|accessdate=16 November 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150625035824/http://www.amiba.net/resources/news-archive/amazon-nexus-subsidiaries|archivedate=25 June 2015}}</ref> via distribution centers and wholly owned subsidiaries.
Amazon says it would support a federal solution to the sales tax problem as long as such legislation was fair and simple.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} As of May 2011 legislation has been introduced in Congress to allow states to impose sales taxes on sales to their residents from out-of-state.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} Amazon has not stated a public position on the bill. Amazon's competitors say it is insincere. Similar legislation, called the [[Main Street Fairness Act]], failed in committee in 2010. Several earlier versions of the bill also failed to advance. Amazon lobbyists met four times with members of Congress or their aides in 2010 regarding the Main Street Fairness Act. The company spent $100,000 on lobbying in 2010, although these expenses also covered other bills discussed at the same time. Amazon has increased political contributions to federal lawmakers. Amazon's [[political action committee]] spent $214,000 during the 2010 election cycle, double what it spent for the 2008 elections.<ref name="Durbin">{{cite news|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/battle-over-internet-sales-taxes-rekindles-in-congress/|title=Battle over Internet sales taxes rekindles in Congress|first=Kyung M.|date=May 21, 2011|work=|newspaper=Seattle Times|via=|author=Song|accessdate=November 11, 2016}}</ref>
==State legislation== Not all states listed below have instituted Amazon laws. State responses have varied widely. In many cases, Amazon has started collecting sales taxes because they have opened up a fulfillment center or some other physical presence in the state. In other cases, states have entered into agreements with Amazon to collect sales taxes, but formal laws have not been passed. Finally, some states have passed laws that require out-of-state retailers to either collect sales tax or notify buyers that they are responsible for reporting their owed sales tax to state tax authorities. During the first wave of "Amazon laws", many states determined that if an affiliate or other entity in the state received compensation for referrals to an online retailer, then that constituted a nexus in the state and hence retailers were liable for collecting sales taxes. In many cases, after these laws were passed, Amazon shut down its affiliate program in those states and was able to avoid collecting sales taxes. Other states (such as New York) took stricter stances and required online retailers to collect sales taxes on all sales and shipments to residents of their states whether or not the retailer had a physical presence in the state.<ref name="New York">Hansell, Saul. [http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/05/01/amazon-sues-new-york-state-to-void-sales-tax-rules/ "Amazon Sues New York State to Void Sales Tax Rules"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. May 1, 2008.</ref> Finally, many agreements and laws require Amazon and other online retailers to only collect state sales tax, not local sales taxes.
===Alabama=== On October 1, 2015, [[Alabama]] allowed retailers to voluntarily join their Simplified Sellers Use Tax program in which sellers would collect a flat 8% sales tax no matter where they shipped to within the state. Alabama's law also allows them to lock in the 8 percent rate even if the federal government adopts a higher figure in the future. The tax applies to all sales regardless of where they are shipped in the state.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.al.com/news/index.ssf/2016/08/why_amazon_shoppers_in_alabama.html|title=Why Amazon shoppers in Alabama will soon be paying more|first=|date=August 15, 2016|accessdate=February 1, 2017}}</ref> Furthermore, if sellers paid on time, they would be able to keep 2% and only remit 6% to Alabama. As a condition of joining the program, sellers agree to maintain records of all sales into Alabama, including purchaser name and address as well as purchase amount and taxes collected.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Magee|first1=Julie|title=State of Alabama Department of Revenue Notice|url=https://revenue.alabama.gov/salestax/Simplified_SLU_Notice_20150902.pdf|accessdate=1 April 2017|agency=State of Alabama Department of Revenue}}</ref> Then, on January 1, 2016, new rules promulgated by the Alabama Department of Revenue required any out-of-state sellers doing more than $250,000 in sales to Alabama residents would be required to collect sales tax. This appears to be in contradiction to [[Quill Corp. v. North Dakota]].<ref>{{cite web|title=New Alabama Regulation to Require Out-of-State Sell ers to Collect Sales and Use Tax Contrary to Supreme Court Precede nt|url=https://www.grantthornton.com/~/media/content-page-files/tax/pdfs/SALT-alerts-states-A-L/AL/2015/AL-Quill-Reg-10-30-15.ashx|website=grantthornton.com|accessdate=1 April 2017}}</ref>
As of November 1, 2016, Amazon started collecting state sales tax by participating in Alabama's Simplified Use Tax Remittance Program, joining over 50 other retailers that had joined the program.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gore|first1=Leada|title=Amazon shoppers in Alabama: Your bill is going up by 8 percent on Nov. 1|url=http://www.al.com/news/index.ssf/2016/10/amazon_shoppers_in_alabama_you.html|accessdate=1 April 2017|agency=AL.com|date=October 26, 2016}}</ref>
===Arizona=== On October 26, 2012, Amazon reached an agreement with the [[Arizona]] Department of Revenue to pay $53 million to settle unpaid sales taxes. Furthermore, effective February 1, 2013, Amazon agreed to begin collecting sales taxes for goods sold to Arizonans. Furthermore, on July 1, 2013, Amazon would also begin collecting sales tax on digital products or services, like books. Amazon only agreed to collect the 6.6% state sales tax, but there was no requirement to collect local sales taxes, which can bring total tax close to 10%.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://tucson.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/amazon-com-will-collect-az-sales-tax/article_42163cee-877f-54d8-a97b-6630df3242a1.html|title=Amazon.com will collect AZ sales tax|date=October 27, 2012|accessdate=March 9, 2017}}</ref> This was an agreement between Amazon and Arizona, which mainly centered on Amazon's tax obligations because it maintains warehouses in Arizona. Arizona does not have a state law forcing other online retailers to collect sales tax if they do not have a physical nexus in Arizona.
===Arkansas=== In 2011, [[Arkansas]] passed a bill requiring Amazon to collect sales tax. The bill took advantage of Amazon's use of affiliates based in Arkansas to establish the necessary physical nexus. Amazon responded by terminating the contracts of its Arkansas-based affiliates effective July 24, 2011.<ref name="Wired">{{cite news |title=Amazon to Connecticut, Arkansas: ‘Drop Dead’ Over Sales Tax |author=Sam Gustin |url=https://www.wired.com/epicenter/2011/06/amazon-conn-ark/ |newspaper=Wired |date=June 14, 2011 |accessdate=June 14, 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110627205552/http://www.wired.com/epicenter/2011/06/amazon-conn-ark/| archivedate= June 27, 2011 | deadurl= no}}</ref> As of March 1, 2017, Amazon will be charging Arkansas residents sales tax after legislation was being moved to collect sales taxes from online retailers. Whether Amazon collects local sales taxes is unclear.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brantley|first=Max|title= Amazon set to begin collecting sales tax on Arkansas purchases in March |url=http://www.arktimes.com/ArkansasBlog/archives/2017/02/10/amazon-set-to-begin-collecting-sales-tax-on-arkansas-purchases-in-march|date=February 10, 2017|accessdate=March 9, 2017}}</ref> Arkansas is currently considering two bills that would require online retailers to collect sales tax (SB 140) or notify Arkansas residents that they owe sales taxes to the Arkansas government (HB 1388).<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nelson|first1=Brooke|last2=Caputo|first2=Ibby|title=Online sales tax legislation advances|url=http://www.arktimes.com/ArkansasBlog/archives/2017/02/02/online-sales-tax-legislation-advances|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=Arkansas Times|date=2 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=HB1388 TO REQUIRE OUT-OF-STATE SELLERS AND FACILITATORS TO PROVIDE NOTICE TO ARKANSAS PURCHASERS REGARDING TAX DUE ON CERTAIN PURCHASES AND TO REPORT SALES MADE TO ARKANSAS PURCHASERS.|url=http://www.arkleg.state.ar.us/assembly/2017/2017R/Pages/BillInformation.aspx?measureno=hb1388|date=January 30, 2017|accessdate=March 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=SB140 TO PROVIDE FOR THE COLLECTION OF SALES AND USE TAX RATHER THAN USE TAX ON SALES BY CERTAIN REMOTE SELLERS.|url=http://www.arkleg.state.ar.us/assembly/2017/2017R/Pages/BillInformation.aspx?measureno=sb140|date=January 18, 2017|accessdate=March 9, 2017}}</ref>
In April 2017, Amazon began collecting sales tax in the state.<ref name="Tax"/>
===California=== In 2009, [[California]] representative [[Nancy Skinner (California politician)|Nancy Skinner]] pushed legislation to tax online sales that was approved as part of the state budget. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger vetoed the legislation.<ref name="latimes">{{cite news|title=California lawmaker pushes to tax online sales|author=Marc Lifsher|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jan/20/business/la-fi-internet-tax-20110120|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=January 20, 2011|accessdate=November 11, 2016}}</ref> On January 19, 2011 Skinner introduced similar legislation in the form of AB153 that later became law. The bill required out-of-state online sellers with affiliates in California to collect sales tax on purchases made by state residents. The affiliate provision was included to ensure that only sellers with a California [[state income tax#Nexus|nexus]] are taxed, as required by federal law.<ref name="sfgate">[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/01/18/BUD01HA47M.DTL#ixzz1BU8jUxBz Russian investment gives Plastic Logic flexibility], by Andrew S. Ross, The San Francisco Chronicle, January 19, 2011</ref> "This legislation will close the current loophole in tax law that has allowed out-of-state companies to avoid collecting California sales and use tax," stated Skinner.<ref name="latimes"/> Skinner estimated that AB153 could produce between $250 million and $500 million per year in new revenue. She and other supporters of the bill believe that the election of Jerry Brown to the governorship and support from retailers such as Barnes & Noble will help the measure become law.<ref name="sacbee1">[http://blogs.sacbee.com/capitolalertlatest/2011/01/major-retailers-back-bid-for-a.html Major retailers back bid for 'Amazon tax'], by Kevin Yamamura, Sacramento Bee, January 20, 2011</ref>
In 2011, Amazon threatened to terminate roughly 10,000 of its affiliates located in California if legislation pending in the state legislature to deem such affiliates as constituting a nexus that requires the collection of sales tax is passed. California affiliates would no longer receive commissions on referrals to Amazon.<ref>{{cite news |title=Amazon makes threats over Calif. sales tax bills |author=Jan Norman|url=http://www.ocregister.com/articles/tax-290753-california-amazon.html |newspaper=Orange County Register |date=March 4, 2011 |accessdate=March 10, 2011}}</ref> As of March 2011, four bills are pending in the state legislature that would define the use of associates located in California-* for sales referrals as activity subject to taxation by California. In a letter addressed to California's Board of Equalization, the agency responsible for collecting sales taxes, Amazon called such legislation "unconstitutional" and said it would terminate its California affiliates if passed. "If any of these new tax collection schemes were adopted, Amazon would be compelled to end its advertising relationships with well over 10,000 California-based participants in the Amazon 'Associates Program,'" wrote Paul Misener, Amazon's Vice President for Global Public Policy.
Responding to Amazon, Nancy Skinner said, "This is really about e-fairness. It's really to be fair and show our California Businesses that we're not hanging them out to dry."<ref>{{cite news |title=State to Amazon.com: Charge Sales Tax |author= Scott Weber |url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/politics/State-to-Amazoncom-Charge-Sales-Tax-118939354.html |publisher=nbcloasangeles.com |date=March 31, 2011 |accessdate=January 26, 2013}}</ref> According to the [[American Independent Business Alliance]], the corporation has operations in at least seven California cities and should be forced to collect sales tax regardless of its threats.<ref name="amiba"/>
In July 2011, Amazon made good on its promises to terminate California affiliates. According to the Performance Marketing Association, there were 25,000 Amazon affiliates based in California.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/business/technology/article/Amazon-cuts-off-California-affiliates-over-sales-2080200.php|title=Amazon cuts off California affiliates over sales tax|first=Rachel|date=June 30, 2011|work=|newspaper=SFGate|via=|author=Metz|accessdate=November 11, 2016}}</ref> However, on Amazon's website, under "United States Subsidiaries," listed are four California locations for [[A2Z Development Center Inc]]. - "an innovative customer-centric software development company" - including in San Francisco and Cupertino, where the Kindle was designed; a search engine company called [[A9.com]] in Palo Alto; and, in San Francisco, [[Alexa Internet]], another Amazon search company.<ref>{{cite news |title=Internet sellers must collect tax, like it or not|author=Andrew S. Ross |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/06/30/BUI31K4P1U.DTL |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |date=July 1, 2011 |accessdate=July 7, 2011}}</ref>
Due to its opposition to rules that would require the company to collect sales tax, Amazon.com is facing a boycott from a coalition of California non-profits. One of the groups behind the boycott, [[Think Before You Click CA]], says improved sales tax enforcement will bring in $200 million per year in additional revenue and encourage people to shop at local traditional retailers instead of online.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/08/16/amazon-boycott-sales-tax_n_928085.html |title=Amazon Boycott Over Internet Sales Tax Gains Momentum |newspaper=The Huffington Post |date=August 16, 2011 |accessdate=August 18, 2011 |first=Andrew |last=Losowsky}}</ref>
====Compromise with Amazon.com==== In response to resistance from Amazon.com, other online retailers, and anti-tax groups, the State of California agreed to a delay of one year before requiring online retailers to begin collecting sales tax on sales to California addresses.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.beaconequity.com/smw/12429/Postponing-Online-Tax-Bill-Helps-Create-More-Jobs|title=Postponing Online Tax Bill Helps Create More Jobs|date=13 September 2011|accessdate=16 November 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120109071910/http://www.beaconequity.com/smw/12429/Postponing-Online-Tax-Bill-Helps-Create-More-Jobs|archivedate=9 January 2012}}</ref> In return for the one-year delay, Amazon.com says it will create 10,000 full-time jobs, 25,000 seasonal jobs, invest $500 million in various facilities in California over the next few years, and begin remitting sales taxes on orders shipped to California.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} California began collecting sales taxes on September 15, 2012 and the rate will depend upon where the buyer is located. However, this requirement may not apply to third-party sellers on Amazon.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/sep/15/business/la-fi-mo-amazon-collecting-ca-sales-tax-20120915|title =Free ride is over--Amazon.com collecting California sales tax|date = 15 September 2012|accessdate = 9 March 2017}}</ref>
===Colorado=== In response to HB 10-1193 passed in 2010, Amazon terminated its relationship with all affiliates located in [[Colorado]]. The bill originally sought to tax sales to Colorado residents by online retailers with Colorado affiliates. The bill was amended to remove all reference to affiliates in order to discourage Amazon from cutting ties with them. The final bill required large online retailers to either remit tax on sales to Colorado residents or provide information on Colorado customers to the state. In spite of this move Amazon still decided to terminate its Colorado affiliates.<ref>{{cite news |title=Amazon Reacts To Colorado Internet Sales Tax Measure By Firing Its Colorado Associates |author=Dave Taylor |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/03/08/amazon-reacts-to-colorado_n_490028.html |newspaper=The Huffington Post |date=March 8, 2010 |accessdate=February 24, 2011}}</ref>
Amazon began collecting sales tax in Colorado on February 1, 2016.<ref>{{cite news |title=Amazon sales tax collection begins in Colorado, but how much it's collecting remains a mystery |author=Greg Avery |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/blog/boosters_bits/2016/02/amazon-sales-tax-collection-begins-in-colorado-but.html |newspaper=Denver Business Journal |date=February 1, 2016 |accessdate=February 2, 2016}}</ref> On February 23, 2016, the Federal 10th Circuit Court of Appeals court upheld the law against a legal challenge by the Direct Marketing Association. Ruling Judge Neil M. Gorsuch contended that overturning the law would create a statewide "tax shelter" for online retailers. Following the ruling, policy experts predicted that the decision could lead to a unified push for national internet sales taxes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.denverpost.com/business/ci_29552504/colorados-amazon-tax-law-upheld-federal-appeals-court|title=Colorado's 'Amazon Tax' law upheld in federal appeals court|last=Chuang|first=Tamara|date=February 23, 2016|website=www.denverpost.com|publisher=Digital First Media|access-date=February 23, 2016}}</ref> It is unclear whether or not Amazon collects local taxes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/blog/boosters_bits/2016/02/amazon-sales-tax-collection-begins-in-colorado-but.html|title=Amazon sales tax collection begins in Colorado, but how much it's collecting remains a mystery|date=February 1, 2016|access-date=March 8, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.taxrates.com/blog/2016/01/22/amazon-to-collect-colorado-sales-tax-february-2016/|title=Amazon to Collect Colorado Sales Tax, February 2016|date=January 22, 2016|access-date=March 8, 2016}}</ref>
===Connecticut=== In May 2011, [[Connecticut]] Gov. [[Dannel P. Malloy]] signed legislation that requires online retailers to collect sales tax if they have affiliates in the state. The legislation aims to raise $9.4 million. Amazon said Connecticut’s legislation violates [[Quill Corporation v. North Dakota]] and immediately moved to terminate its affiliate relationships in Connecticut. Amazon accused traditional retailers such as Wal-Mart of being behind Connecticut's new law.<ref name="Wired"/>
“We opposed this new tax law because it is unconstitutional and counterproductive. It was supported by big-box retailers, most of which are based outside Connecticut, that seek to harm the affiliate advertising programs of their competitors. Similar legislation in other states has led to job and income losses, and little, if any, new tax revenue," Amazon said in a letter to its affiliates.<ref name="Wired"/>
Amazon has agreed to collect state sales tax of 6.35% in CT starting November 1, 2013. Amazon has also agreed to invest $50 million in Connecticut and to create hundreds of new full-time jobs in the state.<ref>{{cite web|author=Dan Carroll, The Motley Fool |url=http://www.ctpost.com/business/fool/article/Amazon-to-Collect-Connecticut-Sales-Tax-4252582.php |title=Amazon to Collect Connecticut Sales Tax - Connecticut Post |publisher=Ctpost.com |date=February 5, 2013 |accessdate=May 25, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.courant.com/2013-10-29/business/hc-amazon-tax-november-20131029_1_in-state-brick-and-mortar-operations-sales-taxes-marketplace-fairness-act |title=Amazon To Start Collecting Sales Tax Friday|date=October 29, 2013 |accessdate=March 8, 2017}}</ref>
===District of Columbia=== Amazon began collecting DC's 5.75% sales tax on October 1, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sturdivant|first1=Christina|title=D.C. Customers Will Have To Pay Sales Tax On Amazon Orders|url=http://dcist.com/2016/09/amazon_sales_tax_dc.php|accessdate=11 March 2017|agency=DCist|date=20 September 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161201164404/http://dcist.com/2016/09/amazon_sales_tax_dc.php|archivedate=December 1, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Clabaugh|first1=Jeff|title=Amazon says it will start charging sales tax in DC|url=http://wtop.com/money/2016/09/amazon-says-it-will-start-charging-sales-tax-in-dc/|accessdate=11 March 2017|agency=WTOP|date=16 September 2016}}</ref>
===Florida=== In a 2012 editorial supporting tax equity, the [[Florida]] ''[[St. Petersburg Times]]'' wrote, "As long as Internet-only sellers such as Amazon.com can get away with not collecting state [[sales tax]] and effectively sell their products for at least 6 percent less, Florida merchants pay the price. It's past time for lawmakers to work toward a level playing field."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tampabay.com/opinion/editorials/close-internet-sales-tax-loophole/1152459|title=Close Internet sales tax loophole|first=|date=February 19, 2011|work=|newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|via=|author=|accessdate=April 3, 2012}}</ref>
In May 2014, Amazon started collecting sales tax in Florida after starting plans to build two warehouses in the state.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/moneybox/2014/05/01/amazon_and_sales_tax_the_online_retailer_began_collecting_sales_tax_in_florida.html|title=Collecting Sales Tax on Amazon Purchases Doesn’t Really Help Local Businesses|last=Griswold|first=Alison|date=May 1, 2014|publisher=Slate Magazine|access-date=November 11, 2016|work=slate.com}}</ref> Amazon agreed to collect the state sales tax of 6%, but there was no mention of collecting local sales taxes <ref>{{cite web|url=http://miami.cbslocal.com/2013/10/23/amazon-to-open-two-warehouses-in-florida/|title=Amazon To Open Two Warehouses In Florida|date=October 23, 2013|accessdate=March 8, 2017}}</ref>
===Georgia=== [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] had passed a law that became effective in January 2012 expanding the definition of what constituted a physical presence in the state in hopes that it would force online retailers to begin collecting sales taxes. However, Amazon did not collect sales taxes until Amazon agreed to start collecting Georgia sales tax on September 1, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ajc.com/news/breaking-news/amazon-start-collecting-sales-tax-georgia-sept/yNUezSKZXnDBuO6DPkHwFO/|title= Amazon to start collecting sales tax in Georgia on Sept. 1|date=August 9, 2013|accessdate=March 8, 2017}}</ref>
===Hawaii=== In January 2017, [[Hawaii]] state lawmakers were considering legislation requiring Amazon and other online retailers to collect sales tax.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/news/2017/01/09/hawaii-sees-potential-in-internet-sales-tax.html|title=Hawaii sees potential in internet sales tax|date=January 9, 2017|accessdate=March 8, 2017}}</ref> Amazon began to collect a 4% state sales tax, beginning April 1, 2017.<ref name="Tax"/>
===Idaho=== Amazon began collecting [[Idaho]]'s 6% sales tax from customers who reside in Idaho beginning Saturday, April 1, 2017.<ref name="Tax"/>
===Illinois=== [[Illinois]] passed legislation to tax online sales made to consumers located in the state. In March 2011 Gov. Pat Quinn signed the "Main Street Fairness Act," which targets online retailers with Illinois affiliates. Quinn said the act would help create fair competition and generate more revenue for the state. Illinois estimates that it loses $153 million in sales taxes every year because out-of-state retailers do not remit sales tax on purchases made by Illinois residents. Some online retailers have responded to this legislation and similar efforts in other states by threatening income tax revenues collected from their online affiliates. Amazon, along with Overstock.com, has threatened to terminate affiliates in states that demand that sales tax be collected by online retailers, including Illinois.<ref name="binsider">[http://www.businessinsider.com/the-looming-online-business-battle-2011-1#ixzz1BU8GHi3n Amazon's Fight With Illinois Is A Small Part Of A Bigger Global Battle Between Online Retailers And Tax Authorities], by Paul Wallbank, Business Insider, January 18, 2011</ref> Wal-Mart responded by inviting online businesses based in Illinois to join its affiliate network.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/usa-states-salestax-idUSN1719407020110317|title=States, business watch for effects of Illinois tax|first=Ben|date=March 17, 2011|work=|newspaper=Reuters|via=|author=Klayman|accessdate=November 11, 2016}}</ref>
The Illinois Policy Institute has said that the law has been "all pain and no gain." While it was "sold as a significant revenue raiser and a step toward improved tax fairness, it is accomplishing little more than pushing online entrepreneurs out of state."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.illinoispolicy.org/reports/all-pain-and-no-gain-why-lawmakers-should-put-the-affiliate-nexus-law-on-hold/|title=Illinois Policy Institute - All pain and no gain: Why lawmakers should put the affiliate nexus law on hold|last=Rasmussen|first=Kristina|date=October 26, 2011|website=Illinois Policy|publisher=Illinoispolicy.org|accessdate=November 11, 2016}}</ref>
The law was declared [[unconstitutional]] in October 2013 by the [[Illinois Supreme Court]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/breaking/chi-illinois-amazon-tax-20131018,0,170299.story |title=Illinois Supreme Court strikes down 'Amazon tax' |publisher=Chicago Tribune |date=October 18, 2013 |accessdate=October 18, 2013}}</ref> because it applied only to online businesses. Illinois subsequently passed similar legislation which applied to "catalog, mail-order and similar retailers along with online sellers... if they have sales of $10,000 or more in the prior year." Although the law went into effect January 1, 2015, retailers were given an additional month to comply with the legislation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2015/jan/19/new-rules-help-illinois-collect-out-of-state-sales |title=New rules help Illinois collect out-of-state sales taxes |publisher=Washington Times |date=January 19, 2015 |accessdate=January 23, 2015}}</ref> Online retailers are required to collect the 6.25% state sales tax, but do not have to collect local sales taxes in addition to the state rate.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Elejalde-Ruiz|first1=Alexia|last2=Karp|first2=Gregory|title=Amazon to start collecting Illinois sales tax|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-amazon-sales-tax-illinois-0124-biz-2-20150123-story.html|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=Chicago Tribune|date=23 January 2015}}</ref>
Amazon announced in October that it plans to build several facilities in Illinois by 2017, including the first this year, which eventually would have required it to collect the state's use tax.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/breaking/ct-amazon-sales-tax-illinois-0124-biz-2-20150123-story.html#page=1|title=Amazon to start collecting Illinois sales tax|last=Elejalde-Ruiz|first=Alexia|date=January 23, 2015|work=|last2=Karp|first2=Gregory|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|access-date=November 11, 2016|via=}}</ref>
===Indiana=== [[Indianapolis]] based [[Simon Property Group]] sued the state in 2011 to force it to collect sales tax from Amazon in an attempt to level the playing field.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-11-03/simon-property-group-sues-indiana-over-e-commerce-sales-tax.html|title=Simon Property Sues Indiana Over Failure to Tax Amazon E-Commerce Sales|last=|first=|date=November 3, 2011|work=|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|subscription=yes|via=|accessdate=December 2, 2014}}</ref> In a settlement deal brokered by Gov. Mitch Daniels in January 2012, Amazon agreed to collect sales tax from Indiana residents beginning January 1, 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/09/us-amazon-salestax-idUSTRE80823120120109|title=Amazon, Indiana strike state sales tax deal|last=Barr|first=Alistair|date=January 9, 2012|work=|publisher=Reuters|via=|accessdate=December 2, 2014}}</ref> Amazon owns four distribution centers in Indiana, which satisfies the physical requirement.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://indianapublicmedia.org/news/amazon-begins-charging-sales-tax-indiana-60811/|title=Amazon Begins Charging Sales Tax In Indiana|last=Frazee|first=Gretchen|date=January 2, 2014|work=|publisher=Indiana Public Media|via=|accessdate=December 2, 2014}}</ref>
===Iowa=== On January 1, 2017, Amazon began collecting 6% sales tax in [[Iowa]].<ref name="georgecford">{{cite web|url=http://www.thegazette.com/subject/news/business/consumers/amazoncom-to-begin-collecting-iowa-sales-tax-sunday-20161230|title=Amazon.com to begin collecting Iowa sales tax Sunday|last=Ford|first=George|date=December 30, 2016|publisher=[[The Gazette (Cedar Rapids)]]|access-date=January 9, 2017}}</ref> As Amazon has no physical presence in Iowa, it is not compelled by law to collect state sales tax. Amazon will not collect the local option portion of the sales tax.
===Kansas=== Amazon has collected sales tax in [[Kansas]] since at least 2005 even though it opened up a distribution center back in 1999, which satisfies the physical presence requirement that often forces retailers to collect sales taxes.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Davis|first1=Carl|title=Why Online Holiday Shopping Will Cost More This Year|url=http://www.taxjusticeblog.org/archive/2015/11/a_20_second_look_at_amazons_sa.php|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=Institute for Taxation and Economic Policy|date=23 November 2015}}</ref> Proposed Senate Bill 111 would require online retailers to notify Kansas residents of their sales tax liabilities if the retailer does not collect sales taxes on the transaction.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Salazar|first1=Daniel|title=Colorado’s ‘Amazon tax’ inspires Kansas bill|url=http://www.kansas.com/news/politics-government/article131594784.html|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=Witchita Eagle|date=8 February 2017}}</ref>
===Kentucky=== Amazon has collected sales tax in [[Kentucky]] since 2005 according to the Tax Justice Blog, but Amazon has maintained a distribution center in Kentucky since at least 1999.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Carl|first1=Davis|title=Why Online Holiday Shopping Will Cost More This Year|url=http://www.taxjusticeblog.org/archive/2015/11/a_20_second_look_at_amazons_sa.php|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=Institute for Tax and Economic Policy|date=23 November 2015}}</ref> Kentucky does not have a law requiring sales tax collection for companies that do not have a physical presence in the state.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kentucky joins national Sales Tax Simplification Agreement|url=https://revenue.ky.gov/Business/Sales-Use-Tax/Documents/SSTPrelease.pdf|website=Kentucky Department of Revenue|publisher=Commonwealth of Kentucky|accessdate=19 December 2017|date=21 July 2005}}</ref>
In a 2011 editorial ''The State'' (A South Carolina paper) criticized the Kentucky incentives given to Amazon to build a distribution center in Lexington. They wrote, with respect to the South Carolina deal, that that deal with Amazon created "...yet another exemption in our Swiss-cheese tax code, and surrender[ed] what little leverage we have to collect taxes on the fastest-growing segment of the retail sector — from which we derive the largest share of the revenue that runs state government. It’s only a small step from giving Amazon a five-year exemption from collecting the sales taxes from S.C. residents to giving that same break to Walmart, Target and all the other businesses that offer online shopping — as one Senate amendment actually proposed to do."<ref>{{cite news|title=We must learn from Amazon, improve policy|first=|date=May 29, 2011|work=|newspaper=The State|via=|author=Editorial}}</ref>
===Louisiana=== As of January 1, 2017, Amazon began collecting sales tax in [[Louisiana]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nola.com/business/index.ssf/2016/12/amazon_louisiana_sales_tax.html |title=Amazon will start charging Louisiana sales tax in 2017 |publisher=NOLA.com |date=December 20, 2016 |accessdate=January 1, 2017}}</ref> Louisiana citizens, whose state has one of the highest average combined sales tax rate in the nation, now pay, on average, 9% in state and local sales and use tax for Amazon purchases.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theadvocate.com/baton_rouge/news/politics/legislature/article_b82b895a-0e5c-5cdf-abd8-2d2015e5b1d1.html |title= Louisiana sales tax system now ranks worse than last place |publisher=New Orleans Advocate |date=April 5, 2016 |accessdate=January 1, 2017}}</ref>
Act 22, passed in on March 14, 2016 requires online retailers to collect sales taxes on online purchases.<ref>{{cite web|title=HB30 TAX/SALES & USE: Provides for the collection of sales and use taxes due on sales made in Louisiana by a remote dealer|url=http://www.legis.la.gov/legis/BillInfo.aspx?s=161ES&b=HB30&sbi=y|date=March 14, 2016|accessdate=March 9, 2017}}</ref>
===Maine=== On April 1, 2017, Amazon started collecting 5.5% sales tax in [[Maine]] following pressure from State officials.
===Maryland=== On October 1, 2014, Amazon started collecting sales tax in [[Maryland]] ahead of a planned opening of a new distribution center in Southeast Baltimore.<ref name="gregbensinger">{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/states-that-make-amazon-pay-sales-taxes-1412185657|title=States That Make Amazon Pay Sales Taxes|last=Bensinger|first=Gary|date=October 1, 2014|publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|access-date=November 11, 2016|subscription=yes|work=www.wsj.com}}</ref> Maryland does not currently require online retailers without a physical presence in the state to collect sales taxes.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mirabella|first1=Lorraine|title=Amazon to start collecting sales tax from Maryland shoppers|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2014-09-28/business/bs-bz-amazon-sales-tax-20140927_1_amazon-prime-sales-tax-online-retailers|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=The Baltimore Sun|date=28 September 2014}}</ref>
===Massachusetts=== On November 1, 2013, Amazon began collecting the states' 6.25% sales tax for [[Massachusetts]] residents. The collection only applies to purchases made on Amazon and not to third-party sellers through Amazon. Amazon is now collecting sales taxes primarily because it now has a physical presence in Massachusetts.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Taryn|first1=Luna|title=Amazon to begin collecting Mass. sales tax Friday|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2013/10/28/amazon-begin-collecting-massachusetts-sales-tax-friday/acyUMexp4ChUk2I6JtdJyI/story.html|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=The Boston Globe|date=29 October 2013}}</ref>
===Michigan=== On October 1, 2015, Amazon started collecting sales tax in [[Michigan]] in accordance with a state law compelling online retailers to do so if they have a physical presence in the state.<ref name="emilylawler">{{cite web|url=http://www.mlive.com/lansing-news/index.ssf/2015/09/michiganders_to_pay_more_at_on.html|title=Michiganders to pay more at online retailers|last=Lawler|first=Emily|date=September 29, 2015|website=www.mlive.com|publisher=MLive Media Group|access-date=November 11, 2016}}</ref>
===Minnesota=== On October 1, 2014, Amazon started collecting sales tax in [[Minnesota]].<ref name="gregbensinger"/> There is no state law compelling it to collect taxes. This decision came ahead of Amazon's decision to open up a distribution center in Shakopee that is opened in early 2017.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Painter|first1=Kristen|last2=Kumar|first2=Kavita|title=Amazon plans to employ 1,000 at new distribution center in Shakopee, seeks tax breaks|url=http://www.startribune.com/amazon-plans-to-employ-1-000-at-new-distribution-center-in-shakopee/300852681/|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=Minnesota Star-Tribune|date=22 April 2015}}</ref>
===Mississippi=== On January 12, 2017, [[Mississippi]]'s chief tax collector filed to require any company doing more than $250,000 of sales in Mississippi each year to collect the state's 7% sales tax. Amazon has already begun collecting sales tax as of February 1, 2017. Furthermore, at least 3 bills have been introduced into the state legislature to require remote retailers to pay sales tax.<ref>{{cite news |author=Associated Press |date=January 25, 2017 |title=Mississippi To Collect Amazon Sales Tax |url=http://wkrg.com/2017/01/25/mississippi-to-collect-amazon-sales-tax/ |access-date=March 9, 2017}}</ref> Mississippi will allow the internet tax bill passed by the house committee on February 1, 2017, to die in committee. Lt. Gov. Tate Reeves called the bill unconstitutional.<ref>{{cite news |first=Adam|last=Ganucheau |date=February 27, 2017 |title=Reeves: Internet sales tax bill is dead|url=http://mississippitoday.org/2017/02/27/reeves-house-internet-sales-tax-bill-is-dead/|access-date=March 9, 2017}}</ref>
===Missouri=== Two legislators in [[Missouri]] have proposed joining the [[Streamlined Sales Tax Project]] to ensure that the state collects sales tax on goods shipped from online retailers located out-of-state. Currently Missourians are required to remit use tax for purchases made online but the state government has no practical method to force compliance. Legislative staff report that taxing online sales should significantly increase revenue. Rep. [[Margo McNeil]] cited a University of Tennessee study saying that Missouri stands to lose $187 million in 2011 by not taxing online sales. McNeil also said the streamlined sales tax is a good way to end the unfair advantages enjoyed by online retailers over traditional businesses. "The tax is a step in trying to even the playing field because right now we have a lot of people who are going in and using the stores as a showroom and then going home and buying on the Internet ...," McNeil said.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.callnewspapers.com/Articles-i-2011-02-16-250937.112112-Legislators-work-to-close-loophole-in-internet-tax-policy.html|title=Legislators work to close loophole in Internet tax policy|first=Matthew|date=February 16, 2011|work=|newspaper=Call|via=|author=Patane|accessdate=November 11, 2016}}</ref>
On February 1, 2017, Amazon began collecting the state portion of the sales tax rate in [[Missouri]] that is 4.225 percent, but does not collect city and county portions of the sales tax rate that is charged on local purchases.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.stltoday.com/business/local/amazon-to-begin-charging-sales-tax-in-missouri/article_6f9bb7b9-53b8-5b88-9a80-cc3f022b51a8.html|title= Amazon to begin charging sales tax in Missouri |first=Lisa|last=Brown|date=January 26, 2017|newspaper=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|accessdate=March 9, 2017}}</ref>
===Nebraska=== Amazon began collecting sales tax in [[Nebraska]] on January 1, 2017. Nebraska does not currently have a law requiring online retailers to collect sales taxes if they do not have a physical presence in the state.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.omaha.com/news/nebraska/amazon-will-begin-collecting-sales-tax-on-purchases-by-nebraskans/article_22b5de6e-ee7e-5410-a333-42d2b8a63af6.html|title=Amazon will begin collecting sales tax on purchases by Nebraskans|website=www.Omaha.com|publisher=The Omaha World Herald|accessdate=December 24, 2016}}</ref> The sales tax in Nebraska is 6%.
===Nevada=== Legislation that would have required Amazon to collect sales tax on purchases shipped to [[Nevada]] failed in committee in the state legislature in May 2011. The legislation was proposed by the Retail Association of Nevada and was expected to generate $16 million annually in additional sales tax collections. Concerns about whether such a move might prompt Amazon.com to close its distribution center in the state were partially responsible for derailing this legislation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/columns-blogs/political-eye/taxation-committee-drops-internet-sales-tax-amendment?ref=894|title=Taxation committee drops Internet sales tax amendment|first=Benjamin|date=May 19, 2011|work=|newspaper=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]|via=|author=Spillman|accessdate=November 11, 2016}}</ref> However, in April 2012, an agreement was reached that would require Amazon to collect sales tax from Nevada customers beginning on January 1, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|last=Vogel|first=Ed|title=Gov. Sandoval reaches sales tax deal with Amazon|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/business/economy/gov-sandoval-reaches-sales-tax-deal-amazon|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|accessdate=June 12, 2013}}</ref> The agreement would include collecting state and local sales taxes.<ref>{{cite news|last=Schwartz|first=David|title= Nevada reaches agreement with Amazon on collection of sales tax |url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/2012/apr/23/nevada-reaches-agreement-amazon-collection-sales-t/|work=Las Vegas Sun|accessdate=March 9, 2017}}</ref> Nevada does not require other online retailers without a physical presence in Nevada to collect sales taxes.
===New Jersey=== Amazon began collecting sales tax in [[New Jersey]] on July 1, 2013.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-05-30/amazon-to-collect-n-j-sales-tax-under-agreement-lawmaker-says.html|title=Amazon To Collect N.J. Sales Tax Under Agreement, Lawmaker Says|last=|first=|date=May 30, 2012|work=Bloomberg L.P.|subscription=yes|via=|accessdate=June 20, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.com/mercer/index.ssf/2013/01/amazon_will_open_robbinsville.html|title=Amazon's prime location: Business experts say distribution hub in Mercer is ideal|last=Griff|first=Martin|date=January 9, 2013|website=www.nj.com|publisher=The Times of Trenton|accessdate=May 25, 2013}}</ref> This was a result of opening up warehouses in New Jersey. New Jersey has not passed a law that would require online retailers without a physical presence to collect sales taxes.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Friedman|first1=Matt|last2=Renshaw|first2=Jarrett|title=Amazon.com to begin collecting sales tax on N.J. orders next year|url=http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2012/05/amazoncom_to_begin_collecting.html|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=Star-Ledger|date=30 May 2012}}</ref>
===New Mexico=== Effective April 1, 2017, Amazon began collecting sales taxes in [[New Mexico]]. New Mexico's Revenue Department says that just over 5 percent sales tax will be collected with some going to the state's general fund and some going to the cities where the product was purchased. This 5 percent is much less than the average combined state and local sales tax of 7.51%.<ref>{{cite news|title=Amazon to Collect Sales Tax in New Mexico Starting in April|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/new-mexico/articles/2017-03-06/amazon-to-collect-sales-tax-in-new-mexico-starting-in-april|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=Associated Press|publisher=U.S. News and World Report|date=6 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Kaeding|first1=Nicole|title=Facts & Figures 2016: How Does Your State Compare?|date=29 February 2016|publisher=Tax Foundation|location=Washington DC|isbn=978-1-942768-08-1|url=https://taxfoundation.org/facts-figures-2016-how-does-your-state-compare/|accessdate=10 March 2017}}</ref>
Several bills are currently under consideration to reform New Mexico's tax laws and force online retailers to collect sales taxes.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dyer|first1=Jessica|title=Amazon to begin collecting taxes in NM next month|url=https://www.abqjournal.com/962831/amazon-to-start-collecting-taxes-in-new-mexico.html|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=Albuquerque Journal|date=6 March 2017}}</ref>
===New York=== In 2008, [[New York (state)|New York]] passed a law that would force online retailers to collect sales taxes on shipments to state residents.<ref name="New York"/> Shortly after the law was signed, Amazon filed a complaint in the [[New York Supreme Court]] objecting to the law.<ref name="New York"/> The complaint wasn't based on whether in-state customers should pay tax, but upon the long-standing practice of it being the responsibility of the customer to report the sales tax (known as [[use tax]] in this case) and not that of the out-of-state businesses.<ref name="New York"/> The lawsuit was tossed out of court in January 2009, when New York State Supreme Court Justice Eileen Bransten stated "there is no basis upon which Amazon can prevail."<ref name="Here come the Judge">Sage, Alexandria and Edith Honan. [https://www.reuters.com/article/internetNews/idUSTRE50C5UN20090113 "NY Judge Tosses amazon.com Lawsuit Over Sales Tax"]. [[Reuters]]. January 13, 2009.</ref>
As of 2011 [[Overstock.com]] is suing New York state to prevent being required to collect sales taxes on goods shipped to New York residents. In order to comply with the physical presence requirement of [[Quill Corp. v. North Dakota]] the law targets out-of-state retailers who make use of New York-based affiliates. Overstock.com argues that the use of affiliates is not enough to meet the physical presence test and that the law thus violates the [[Commerce Clause]]. In addition to filing suit, Overstock.com has terminated its 3,400 affiliates in New York.<ref name="register">[https://www.theregister.co.uk/2008/06/02/overstock_sues_new_york/ Overstock and Patrick Byrne sue New York over Amazon Tax], by Cade Metz, The Register, June 2, 2008</ref>
In early 2017, Governor Cuomo proposed that sales tax collection be applied to Amazon's "Marketplace" operations.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Karlin|first1=Rick|title=New York's expanded 'Amazon tax' to take center stage|url=http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/New-York-s-expanded-Amazon-tax-to-take-center-10892909.php|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=Timesunion|date=29 January 2017}}</ref> In April 2017, Amazon began collecting sales tax in the state.<ref name="Tax"/>
===North Carolina=== Due to former state laws, Amazon did not allow North Carolina residents to participate in the Amazon Affiliates program, however this is no longer the case.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://affiliate-program.amazon.com/gp/associates/agreement|title=Associates Program Operating Agreement|last=|first=|date=November 1, 2016|website=www.amazon.com|publisher=Amazon|access-date=November 11, 2016}}</ref> Starting February 1, 2014, Amazon began collecting NC state sales tax on orders.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wral.com/Amazon_to_collect_NC_sales_tax/13310401/|title=Amazon to collect NC sales tax|last=|first=|date=January 18, 2014|editor-last=Chambers Jr.|editor-first=Stan|publisher=Capitol Broadcasting Company|access-date=November 11, 2016|work=www.wral.com}}</ref>
===North Dakota=== Amazon has collected sales tax in [[North Dakota]] since at least 2001 because they operated a fulfillment center in Grand Forks at that time until 2005. Even after closing the fulfillment center, they still collect sales tax even though North Dakota still has not passed any Amazon tax laws.<ref>{{cite web|title=Amazon Global Fulfillment Center Network|url=http://mwpvl.com/html/amazon_com.html|website=MWPVL International|accessdate=10 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Davis|first1=Carl|title=Why Online Holiday Shopping Will Cost More This Year|url=http://www.taxjusticeblog.org/archive/2015/11/a_20_second_look_at_amazons_sa.php|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=Institute for Tax and Economic Policy|date=23 November 2015}}</ref>
===Ohio=== A study released by the [[University of Cincinnati]] in October 2011 determined that [[Ohio]]'s state government could increase tax revenue by at least $200 million per year if Congress were to require online retailers to collect and remit sales taxes. Ohio consumers who make online purchases are already required to self-report and pay sales tax but compliance is rare. According to the study, even though more than 60 percent of households in the state made at least one purchase from an online retailer in 2010 less than 1 percent of Ohio state income tax returns included tax payments for such purchases.{{Citation needed|date=November 2017}}
On June 1, 2015, Amazon began collecting sales tax in the State of Ohio due to the new data centers that are being built at the Columbus, Ohio area. This satisfies the requirement of a physical presence of Amazon to begin collecting sales tax in the state due to the affiliate owned by Amazon.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.clevescene.com/scene-and-heard/archives/2015/06/03/amazon-is-now-charging-sales-tax-in-ohio|title=Amazon is Now Charging Sales Tax in Ohio|last=Meek|first=Jason|date=June 3, 2015|work=|newspaper=Cleveland Scene|access-date=November 11, 2016|via=}}</ref>
===Oklahoma=== [[Oklahoma]] Governor [[Mary Fallin]] announced in February 2017 that on March 1, Amazon would begin collecting sales taxes on online purchases. This followed the passage by the state legislature of the Oklahoma Retail Protection Act, introduced by Representative Chad Caldwell.<ref>{{cite news|title=Amazon to start collecting sales tax on Oklahoma purchases|url=http://kfor.com/2017/02/02/amazon-to-start-collecting-sales-tax-in-oklahoma/|website=KFOR.com|agency=The Associated Press|date=February 2, 2017|accessdate=February 2, 2017}}</ref> Under the Act, affected retailers are responsible for either collecting and remitting state and local sales tax or notifying their customers of their tax obligations.
===Pennsylvania=== The [[Pennsylvania]] Department of Revenue released a sales tax bulletin on December 1, 2011 outlining the Commonwealth's interpretation of the Tax Reform Code of 1971 (TRC). The bulletin focuses on the Commonwealth's definition of a nexus for the purposes of collecting sales tax, and points out that the TRC defines a business as "maintaining a place of business in this Commonwealth" if that business engages in an activity within the Commonwealth "either directly or through a subsidiary, representative, or agent, in connection with the lease, sale or delivery of tangible personal property."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.revenue.pa.gov/GeneralTaxInformation/TaxLawPoliciesBulletinsNotices/Documents/Tax%20Bulletins/SUT/st_bulletin_2011-01.pdf|title=Sales and Use Tax Bulletin 2011-01|last=|first=|date=December 1, 2011|website=|publisher=[[Pennsylvania Department of Revenue]]|format=pdf|author=Pennsylvania Department of Revenue|accessdate=November 11, 2016}}</ref>
While issuing the sales tax bulletin, Revenue Secretary Dan Meuser said that the Commonwealth would lose an estimated $380 million in 2011 due to the non-collection of online sales taxes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.centralpennbusiness.com/article/20111209/FRONTPAGE/111209823&source=RSS |title=Online sales tax collection could see backlash |last1=Ryan |first1=Jim T. |date=December 9, 2011 |publisher=[[Central Penn Business Journal]] |accessdate=January 31, 2012}}</ref> At issue is the presence of four Amazon Fulfillment Centers located in Pennsylvania. Early in December 2011, Meuser said that if out-of-state sellers who haven’t previously collected state sales tax register and start collecting the taxes by February 1, 2012, then the Commonwealth would not seek payments of back taxes. After this deadline, Meuser said the Commonwealth would take enforcement action seeking back taxes.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/janetnovack/2011/12/06/pa-sales-tax-crackdown-means-grief-for-amazon-merchants/ |title=Pa. Sales Tax Crackdown Means Grief For Amazon Merchants |last1=Novack |first1=Janet |date=December 6, 2011 |publisher=[[Forbes|Forbes Magazine]] |accessdate=January 31, 2012}}</ref> On January 27, 2012, Meuser said that the new tax collection policy was being granted a one time extension until September 1, 2012 because the original "compliance deadline [was] impractical from operational and technical standpoints."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://files.painteractive.org/pr/Revenue/2012/2012-01/Revenue%20Department%20Offers%20One-Time%20Extension%20on%20Nexus%20Compliance%20Deadline%20for%20Remote%20Sellers.pdf|title=Revenue Department Offers One-Time Extension on Nexus Compliance Deadline for Remote Sellers|date=January 27, 2012|website=|publisher=[[Pennsylvania Department of Revenue]]|format=PDF|last1=|first1=|accessdate=January 31, 2012}}</ref> Amazon began collecting sales tax in the state beginning on that September 1 deadline. Currently, Amazon just collects Pennsylvania's 6% sales tax, but does not collect any local sales taxes.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://wesa.fm/post/amazoncom-begin-collecting-pa-sales-tax|title=Amazon to begin collecting Pa. sales tax|date=August 30, 2012|work=|agency=[[Associated Press]]|via=|last1=Jackson|first1=Peter|accessdate=November 11, 2016}}</ref>
===Rhode Island=== On February 1, 2017, Amazon began voluntarily collecting [[Rhode Island]]'s 7% sales tax.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bogdan|first1=Jennifer|title=Amazon.com to collect R.I. sales tax|url=http://www.providencejournal.com/news/20170118/amazoncom-to-collect-ri-sales-tax|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=Providence Journal|date=18 January 2017}}</ref> Back in 2009, Rhode Island had passed a law which would have forced Amazon to collect sales taxes if it had "affiliates" in the state. As a result, Amazon cut ties with its affiliates in Rhode Island.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nesi|first1=Ted|last2=Tomison|first2=Bill|title=Amazon will charge sales tax in RI|url=http://wpri.com/2017/01/18/amazon-will-charge-sales-tax-in-ri/|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=WPRI|date=18 January 2017}}</ref>
===South Carolina=== Amazon had agreed to open a distribution center near Columbia, [[South Carolina]] that would employ 1,200 people in exchange for a five-year exemption from collection of sales taxes from shoppers in South Carolina. The state House of Representatives rejected the deal in April 2011 and Amazon cancelled plans for its distribution center. Amazon resumed negotiations and offered 2,000 jobs in exchange for a sales tax exemption and other incentives. Under a compromise approved by the South Carolina state legislature in May 2011, Amazon agreed to notify South Carolina customers by email that sales tax was owed on their purchases but shoppers would still be responsible for paying the tax by themselves. Governor [[Nikki Haley]] says she plans to allow the bill to become law without signing it.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.istockanalyst.com/business/news/5190107/editorial-a-reversal-on-amazon|title=EDITORIAL: A reversal on Amazon|first=|date=May 30, 2011|work=|newspaper=The Herald|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604075614/http://www.istockanalyst.com/business/news/5190107/editorial-a-reversal-on-amazon|archive-date=June 4, 2011|via=|author=|accessdate=November 11, 2016}}</ref>
In a statement made after the deal for Amazon passed the state House the [[Alliance for Main Street Fairness]] said, “Today’s vote in the South Carolina House of Representatives is just one step in the process, yet it’s unfortunate that the majority of the House favors special deals for one prospective retailer at the expense of our state’s existing employers and their 375,000 employees. The vote is particularly disappointing in light of dubious, last minute promises that certainly appear to have influenced some legislators to switch their vote. We’ll rally our troops and voice our concerns to the Senate where we hope they will come to a more fair and rational decision. The case against this special deal continues to grow on a daily basis."<ref>{{cite press release|title=Main Street Responds To House Vote Battle For Brick-And-Mortar Business Continues |url=http://standwithmainstreet.com/resources/main-street-responds-house-vote |publisher=Alliance for Main Street Fairness |date=May 18, 2011 |accessdate=June 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110827214011/http://standwithmainstreet.com/resources/main-street-responds-house-vote |archivedate=August 27, 2011 |df=mdy }}</ref>
Main Street expressed strong disapproval of the [[South Carolina]] Senate's approval of this arrangement. In a press release Main Street said, “Nobody complained when Amazon was given free land, property tax cuts, job tax credits and a repeal of the limits on weekend sales. But in the end, this special exemption only passed after backroom deals and last-minute promises were made by Amazon officials – something which should disappoint everyone interested in transparency and good government."<ref>{{cite press release|title=Main Street Responds To South Carolina Senate Vote |url=http://standwithmainstreet.com/resources/main-street-responds-south-carolina-senate-vote |publisher=Alliance for Main Street Fairness |date=May 27, 2011 |accessdate=June 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110627005935/http://standwithmainstreet.com/resources/main-street-responds-south-carolina-senate-vote |archivedate=June 27, 2011 |df=mdy }}</ref>
South Carolina has passed legislation that required Amazon and other internet retailers to start collecting sales tax in 2016. Prior to 2016, Amazon was not required to collect sales tax on purchases made by South Carolina residents. However, the company was responsible for notifying South Carolina residents via e-mail that they faced liability for sales tax and residents were still required to report the value of all purchases made on Amazon in the previous year and pay the appropriate sales tax on their South Carolina tax return .<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.auctionbytes.com/cab/cab/abn/y12/m01/i30/s02|title=Amazon Notifies South Carolina Shoppers of Sales Tax Owed|first=Kenneth|date=January 30, 2012|work=|newspaper=EcommerceBytes.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120728003933/http://www.ecommercebytes.com/cab/cab/abn/y12/m01/i30/s02|archive-date=July 28, 2012|via=|author=Corbin|accessdate=January 31, 2012}}</ref> As of January 1, 2016, the tax legislation has expired, meaning that Amazon is now required to collect sales tax at the point of sale from South Carolina residents.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.postandcourier.com/business/delivers-taxes-amazon-must-collect-s-c-sales-taxes-corporate/article_538512e9-3536-591a-b423-11364ccbfb3a.html|title=Amazon must collect S.C. sales taxes, corporate break also ends Amazon ‘in a league of its own’ in online sales E-commerce giant claims almost 25% of retail sales growth|last=Wise|first=Warren|date=31 December 2015|publisher=The Post and Courier|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
===South Dakota=== On February 1, 2017, Amazon agreed to being collecting sales tax in [[South Dakota]]. This followed legislation passed in 2016 requiring retailers to remit sales tax even if they did not have a physical presence in the state.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ferguson|first1=Dana|last2=Sneve|first2=Joe|title=Amazon to collect, remit South Dakota sales tax|url=http://www.argusleader.com/story/news/politics/2017/01/10/live-1-governors-state-state-address/96387152/|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=Argus Leader|date=10 January 2017}}</ref>
===Tennessee=== Amazon attempted to avoid being required to collect [[Tennessee]] sales tax during negotiations with economic development officials to build two warehouses outside of [[Chattanooga]]. Amazon argues that its warehouses are not directly affiliated with the company and thus do not create a nexus that would require the collection of sales taxes. Tennessee revenue officials will not reveal any specific information on a deal with Amazon as they claim doing so would violate state confidentiality laws.<ref name="Tenn">[http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/companies/2011-01-29-amazon-sales-tax_N.htm Tenn. retailers oppose Amazon sales tax pass], by Bonna Johnson, USA Today, January 31, 2011</ref>
A legal opinion by the state attorney general affirmed the constitutionality of a proposed bill in the state legislature that would require Amazon to collect sales tax on goods it ships to Tennessee residents. The opinion also stated that Amazon's construction of distribution centers in the state constitutes a physical nexus.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesfreepress.com/news/2011/jun/29/attorney-general-state-can-force-amazon-taxes/|title=Attorney General: State can force Amazon on taxes|first=Mike|date=June 29, 2011|work=|publisher=Chattanooga Publishing Company|newspaper=Times Free Press|others=Flessner, Dave|via=|author=Pare|accessdate=July 7, 2011}}</ref>
According to study done by the [[University of Tennessee]]'s Center for Business and Economic Research, the Tennessee state government and local governments will lose about $410 million in tax revenue in 2011 due to online sales.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesfreepress.com/news/2011/aug/17/corker-says-internet-sales-tax-collections-will-be/|title=U.S. Sen. Bob Corker says Internet sales tax collections ‘will be resolved’|first=Andy|date=August 17, 2011|work=|publisher=Chattanooga Publishing Company|newspaper=Times Free Press|via=|author=Sher|accessdate=August 18, 2011}}</ref>
On January 1, 2014, Amazon began collecting sales tax on purchases in Tennessee, after a two-year delay from when Governor Haslam signed the online sales tax bill in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=Amazon to start collecting online sales tax in Tennessee next month|url=http://www.wsmv.com/story/24116510/amazon-to-start-collecting-online-sales-tax-in-tennessee-next-month|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=WSMV|date=16 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=HB 2370|url=http://www.capitol.tn.gov/Bills/107/Bill/HB2370.pdf|accessdate=10 March 2017}}</ref> Amazon collects both state and local sales tax.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Flessner|first1=Dave|title=Amazon hurt by new tax rules in Tennessee, other states|url=http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/local/story/2014/apr/30/amazon-hurt-by-new-tax-rules/138795/|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=Times Free Press|date=30 April 2014}}</ref>
===Texas=== In 2010, [[Texas]] sent a demand letter for $269 million in sales taxes that the state argues should have been collected and remitted for sales to Texas customers. This dollar amount covers uncollected taxes from December 2005 to December 2009 and also includes penalties and interest. Texas authorities began an investigation of Amazon's tax status after a May 2008 report by ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' questioned why Amazon does not collect sales tax from Texas customers despite maintaining a distribution center in Irving near the Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport. Amazon argues that this distribution center, owned by Amazon.com KYDC LLC, located at the same address as Amazon's corporate headquarters in Seattle, is a legally separate entity and thus does not establish a physical presence in Texas that would require Amazon to collect sales taxes.<ref name="texas">[http://www.dallasnews.com/business/headlines/20101023-Texas-bills-Amazon-for-millions-in-3631.ece Texas bills Amazon for millions in sales taxes], by Maria Halkias, ''The Dallas Morning News'', October 23, 2010</ref> Amazon has decided to close the [[Irving, Texas|Irving]] distribution center in order to avoid future attempts by Texas to force the collection of sales taxes.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703961104576148634038574352|title=Amazon's Exit Spurs Tax Fight in Texas|last=Campoy|first=Ana|date=February 17, 2011|work=|publisher=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|subscription=yes|via=|accessdate=January 26, 2013}}</ref>
Texas Comptroller Susan Combs faced skeptical questions and criticism from members of the Texas Senate Finance Committee February 16, 2011 over her attempts to collect back sales tax from Amazon.com. Combs replied by saying that all businesses must obey the law "It is our belief that this is a very, very clear issue about nexus. As I say, this started probably because of catalog sales 47 years ago in 1963," said Combs. Combs also cited a Texas law to back up her argument that Amazon is required to collect sales taxes: "A retailer is engaged in business in this state if the retailer: 1.) maintains, occupies, or uses in this state permanently, temporarily, directly, indirectly or through a subsidiary or agent, however named, an office, place of distribution, sales or sample room or place, warehouse, storage place, or any other place of business.”<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kxan.com/dpp/news/politics/combs-defends-amazon-sales-tax-fight|title=Combs defends Amazon sales tax fight|first=|date=16 February 2011|work=|newspaper=Austin News KXAN.com|via=|author=Josh Hinkle|accessdate=16 November 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111132449/http://www.kxan.com/dpp/news/politics/combs-defends-amazon-sales-tax-fight|archivedate=11 January 2012}}</ref> The Dallas Morning News published an editorial supporting Combs' efforts to collect sales tax from Amazon.com on 17 February 2011. The paper wrote, "It defies logic that a book bought online can elude sales tax while the same book bought in a bookstore can’t. A sales transaction is a sales transaction, and if one is taxed, why shouldn’t the other be taxed as well?"<ref>{{cite news |title=Editorial: Texas is right to pursue Amazon for uncollected sales taxes |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/opinion/editorials/20110217-editorial-texas-is-right-to-pursue-amazon-for-uncollected-sales-taxes.ece |newspaper=The Dallas Morning News |date=February 17, 2011 |accessdate=February 24, 2011}}</ref>
In March 2010, State Rep. [[Linda Harper-Brown]] filed House Bill 2719. House Bill 2719 would allow Amazon to avoid Texas sales tax by amending the state tax code to exempt companies or individuals from being classified as retailers or being ordered to provide state agencies with information on purchases made in Texas, if they make use of "only a fulfillment center...or computer server." House Bill 2719 stands in sharp contrast to House Bill 2403, introduced by Rep. [[John Otto (politician)|John Otto]]. House Bill 2403 would close loopholes in the Texas tax code that support Amazon's claim of being exempt from collecting sales tax. <ref name="Statebills">{{cite news|url=http://www.statesman.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/theticker/entries/2011/03/09/competing_bills_in_house_set_b.html?cxntfid=blogs_statesman_business_blog|title=Competing bills in House set battle lines in Amazon fight|first=Barry|date=March 9, 2011|work=|newspaper=Austin Statesman|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716134606/http://www.statesman.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/theticker/entries/2011/03/09/competing_bills_in_house_set_b.html?cxntfid=blogs_statesman_business_blog|archive-date=July 16, 2011|via=|author=Harrell|accessdate=March 10, 2011}}</ref>
Legislation pushed by Rep. John Otto to require Amazon and other online retailers with a physical nexus in the state of Texas to collect and remit sales tax became law in 2011. The legislation deems any company with a store, distribution center, or other place of business in Texas as having a physical nexus there for the purpose of collecting sales tax. Otto said that Amazon contended that they did not need to collect the state sales tax because the company did not have a store front in the state and that a subsidiary owned their distribution center in Irving, Texas.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.yourhoustonnews.com/eastex/news/article_e84f52c3-b195-5dd0-a1f9-53b8e78aa276.html|title=Rep. Otto offers legislative summary|first=Melecio|date=July 3, 2011|work=|publisher=Hearst Newspapers|newspaper=The Eastex Advocate|via=|author=Franco|accessdate=July 7, 2011}}</ref>
In April 2012, Amazon agreed to create 2,500 jobs and invest $200 million in new distribution centers in Texas if the state forgave $269 million in back sales taxes. Under the agreement, Amazon began collecting sales taxes from Texas customers beginning July 1, 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.statesman.com/business/documents-amazon-risking-little-in-texas-sales-tax-2418690.html|title=Documents: Amazon risking little in Texas sales tax deal|first=Laylan|date=|work=|newspaper=Statesman|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120720190945/http://www.statesman.com/business/documents-amazon-risking-little-in-texas-sales-tax-2418690.html|archive-date=July 20, 2012|via=|author=Copelin|accessdate=July 18, 2012}}</ref> Under the agreement, Amazon collects the state sales tax of 6.25%, but likely not local sales tax.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sales-tax deal with Texas is Amazon's latest|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/amazon-tax-sales-idUSL2E8FREMY20120427|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=Reuters|date=27 April 2012}}</ref>
===Utah=== Under [[Utah]] state law, internet retailers are only required to collect sales tax for online sales if they have a physical presence and Amazon does not have a physical presence in Utah. However, on December 7, 2016, Gov. Gary Herbert announced that his 2017 tax plan includes a deal with Amazon to start collecting sales tax on Utah purchases. Amazon began collecting sales tax on January 1, 2017. The details of the deal between the state and Amazon, however, remain confidential.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.ksl.com/?sid=42481629&nid=148|title=Governor announces deal with Amazon to collect sales tax on Utah purchases|date=December 7, 2016|publisher=KSL}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sltrib.com/news/4830230-155/utah-wont-release-details-on-amazon|title=Utah won't release details on Amazon tax deal, says info would give advantage to competitors|date=January 17, 2017|publisher=Salt Lake Tribune}}</ref>
===Vermont=== As of February 1, 2017, Amazon began collecting [[Vermont]]'s 6% state sales tax, ahead of a Vermont statute about internet sales tax due to go into effect in July 2017.<ref>{{cite news|title=Amazon will start collecting sales tax in Vermont|url=http://www.wcax.com/story/34311598/amazon-will-start-collecting-sales-tax-in-vermont|accessdate=10 March 2017|agency=WCAX News|date=23 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Amazon to begin collecting 6 percent sales tax in VT|url=http://www.burlingtonfreepress.com/story/money/2017/01/23/amazon-begin-collecting-6-percent-sales-tax-vt-vermont/96939676/|accessdate=11 March 2017|agency=Associated Press|date=23 January 2017}}</ref> Online retailers will not be required to collect the 1% local sales tax that many Vermont towns impose.<ref>{{cite news|title=Editorial: Vermont wins with 'Amazon tax'|url=http://www.burlingtonfreepress.com/story/opinion/editorials/2017/02/01/editorial-vermont-wins-amazon-tax/97240142/|accessdate=11 March 2017|agency=Burlington Free Press|date=1 February 2017}}</ref>
===Virginia=== As of January 2012, [[Virginia]] state senator Frank Wagner has introduced legislation that would require companies with a distribution center, warehouse, fulfillment center, office, or other such location in the Commonwealth of Virginia to collect and remit sales tax. Amazon has announced its intent to build two distribution centers in Richmond. This legislation is supported by the Alliance for Main Street Fairness.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wdbj7.com/news/wdbj7-virginia-general-assembly-sales-tax-legislation-targets-amazoncom-20120130,0,437201.story|title=Virginia legislation targets Amazon.com|last=Dashiell|first=Joe|date=January 30, 2012|work=|newspaper=WDBJ7.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130222173937/http://articles.wdbj7.com/2012-01-30/sales-tax_31007717|archive-date=February 22, 2013|via=|accessdate=January 31, 2012}}</ref> This legislation was passed in early 2013 with an effective date of September 1, 2013. The only retailers to be affected by this bill, since it only clarifies what qualifies as a physical nexus, are Amazon and backcountry.com.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Paitsel|first1=Nicole|title='Amazon tax' takes effect Sept. 1|url=http://articles.dailypress.com/2013-08-30/features/dp-nws-amazon-law-effect-20130830_1_sales-tax-amazon-tax-marketplace-fairness-act|accessdate=11 March 2017|agency=Daily Press|date=30 August 2013}}</ref>
On January 22, 2012, [[Bob McDonnell|Gov. Robert F. McDonnell’s]] office announced that an agreement that Amazon.com would begin collecting state sales tax had been reached with Amazon.com and members of the [[Virginia General Assembly|General Assembly]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/virginia-politics/post/amazon-loophole-to-close-in-virginia/2012/02/22/gIQAHVM2TR_blog.html|title=‘Amazon loophole’ to close in Virginia|date=February 22, 2012|work=|publisher=The Washington Post|via=|last1=Vozzella|first1=Laura|accessdate=February 23, 2012}}</ref> The announcement notes that Amazon.com began collecting and remitting Virginia sales tax on September 1, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.richmond.com/business/amazon-to-start-collecting-sales-taxes/article_20ce223a-4f9f-5af9-9af4-5282e775401e.html|title=Amazon to start collecting sales taxes|date=February 23, 2012|website=www.richmond.com|publisher=BH Media Group|last1=Blackwell|first1=John Reid|accessdate=February 23, 2012}}</ref>
===West Virginia=== Starting on October 1, 2013, Amazon began collecting sales tax in [[West Virginia]]. This was after West Virginia passed a law requiring out-of-state retailers to apply sales tax if they or a subsidiary have a physical presence in the state.<ref>{{cite news|title=Amazon to collect 6 percent sales tax in West Virginia|url=http://www.register-herald.com/news/amazon-to-collect-percent-sales-tax-in-west-virginia/article_4a959924-ceee-54d4-8a93-8e972b9e63d7.html|accessdate=11 March 2017|agency=Associated Press|publisher=The Register-Herald|date=23 September 2013}}</ref>
===Washington=== In 2008, Amazon began collecting sales tax in [[Washington (state)|Washington]], their home state, after a state law was passed requiring in-state online retailers to collect sales tax.<ref name="Tax"/> On January 1, 2018, Amazon began enforcing and collecting tax on third-party merchant sales to Washington state customers, as required by a new state law. Washington was the first to have this policy enforced, with plans to bring merchant order taxes to other states in the future. <ref>https://www.cnbc.com/2017/11/15/amazon-marketplace-tax-collection-comes-to-washington-in-2018.html</ref>
===Wisconsin=== Amazon began collecting sales taxes in [[Wisconsin]] on November 1, 2013, about a year before its Kenosha distribution center was set to open. <ref>{{cite news|last1=Daykin|first1=Tom|title=Amazon.com will start collecting sales tax from Wisconsin customers|url=http://archive.jsonline.com/business/amazoncom-will-start-collecting-sales-tax-from-wisconsin-customers-b99117685z1-227274921.html|accessdate=11 March 2017|agency=Milwaukee-Wisconsin Journal Sentinel|date=10 October 2013}}</ref> Amazon will only be collecting the 5% state sales tax, but not the local sales tax.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Temple-West|first1=Patrick|title=Wisconsin adds sales tax to Amazon.com shopping cart|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-tax-wisconsin-idUSBRE99G0LM20131017|accessdate=11 March 2017|agency=Reuters|date=17 October 2013}}</ref> Wisconsin has not passed an Amazon law, Amazon is collecting sales tax because of its distribution center in the state.
===Wyoming=== Starting March 1, 2017, Amazon voluntarily agreed to begin collecting sales tax in [[Wyoming]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Aaron|title=Amazon State Tax in Wyoming|url=http://www.kgwn.tv/content/news/Amazon-State-Tax-in-Wyoming-410608865.html|accessdate=11 March 2017|agency=KGWN|date=12 January 2017}}</ref> On March 1, 2017, Wyoming passed a bill requiring anyone that does more than 200 transactions or over $100,000 in sales in Wyoming to pay state sales tax.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gruver|first1=Mead|title=Wyoming Puts Teeth in Collecting Online Sales Taxes|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/wyoming/articles/2017-03-01/wyoming-puts-teeth-in-collecting-online-sales-taxes|accessdate=11 March 2017|agency=Associated Press|date=1 March 2017}}</ref>
==Affiliates== Amazon in the past was often able to overcome threats from state governments by cutting ties with local partners or leaving the state in question.
