In [[international law]], '''odious debt''', also known as '''illegitimate debt''', is a legal theory that says that [[government debt|the national debt]] incurred by a [[despotic]] [[regime]] should not be enforceable. Such debts are, thus, considered by this doctrine to be personal debts of the regime that incurred them and not debts of the state. In some respects, the concept is analogous to the invalidity of contracts signed under [[coercion]].{{cite book|author1=Robert Howse|title=The Concept of Odious Debt in Public International Law|date=July 2007| publisher=[[UNCTAD]]|location=Geneva |url= http://unctad.org/en/docs/osgdp20074_en.pdf }} Despite antecedents dating back to the 1800s and support from diverse fields such as [[economics]], [[philosophy]], [[political science]], [[history]], and [[law]], odious debt is not part of [[international law]]; in fact, "[n]o national or international tribunal has ever cited Odious Debt as grounds for invalidating a sovereign obligation."Mitu Gulati, Duke University School of Law; Ugo Panizza, The Graduate Institute Geneva and CEPR. The Hausmann-Gorky Effect. Working Paper No. HEIDWP02-2018. Graduate Institute of International and Development Studies, International Economics Department. Instead, international law holds governments strictly liable for all debt incurred by their predecessors. == History == The concept of odious debt was formalized in a 1927 treatise by [[Alexander Nahum Sack]], a [[Russia]]n émigré legal theorist. It was based on two 19th-century precedents—[[Mexico]]'s repudiation of debts incurred by [[Maximilian of Mexico|Emperor Maximilian]], and the denial by the [[United States]] of [[Cuba]]n liability for debts incurred by the [[Spanish colonization of the Americas|Spanish colonial regime]].Graeme Smith (20 November 2011), [https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/a-new-euro-crisis-strategy-deny-the-debt/article2242826 "A new euro crisis strategy: Deny the debt"], ''[[The Globe and Mail]]''[http://scholarship.law.campbell.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1019&context=fac_sw Sarah Ludington et al., ''Applied Legal History: Demystifying the Doctrine of Odious Debts''], 11 THEORETICAL INQUIRIES L. 247, 253 (2010).[http://harvardlawreview.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/1656-1679_Online.pdf ''Developments in the Law — The International Place of Puerto Rico''], 130 HARV. L. REV. 1656 (2017). Sack wrote:
When a despotic regime contracts a debt, not for the needs or in the interests of the state, but rather to strengthen itself, to suppress a popular insurrection, etc, this debt is odious for the people of the entire state. This debt does not bind the nation; it is a debt of the regime, a personal debt contracted by the ruler, and consequently it falls with the demise of the regime. The reason why these odious debts cannot attach to the territory of the state is that they do not fulfil one of the conditions determining the lawfulness of State debts, namely that State debts must be incurred, and the proceeds used, for the needs and in the interests of the State. Odious debts, contracted and utilised for purposes which, to the lenders' knowledge, are contrary to the needs and the interests of the nation, are not binding on the nation – when it succeeds in overthrowing the government that contracted them – unless the debt is within the limits of real advantages that these debts might have afforded. The lenders have committed a hostile act against the people, they cannot expect a nation which has freed itself of a despotic regime to assume these odious debts, which are the personal debts of the ruler.[http://www.jubileeiraq.org/odiousdebt.htm Jubileeiraq.org] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110306000652/http://www.jubileeiraq.org/odiousdebt.htm |date=2011-03-06 }}
Sack theorized that such debts are not enforceable when (1) the lender should have known that (2) the debt was incurred without the consent and (3) without benefit to the populace.[http://scholarship.law.upenn.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1183&context=faculty_scholarship Patrick Bolton & David Skeel, ''Odious Debts or Odious Regimes?''], 70 LAW & CONTEMP. PROBS. 83 (2007). There are many examples of similar debt repudiation.{{cite journal| author1 = Mitu Gulati| author2 = Sarah Ludington| author3= Alfred L. Brophy |title=Applied Legal History: Demystifying the Doctrine of Odious Debts| journal=[[Theoretical Inquiries in Law]] | date =January 2010| volume=11 |issue =1 |pages=247–281| doi=10.2202/1565-3404.1242| url= http://scholarship.law.duke.edu/faculty_scholarship/2840/|publisher=Walter de Gruyter GmbH | issn = 1565-3404}} Chief Justice [[William Howard Taft]], acting as an [[Arbitrator|arbiter]], used the doctrine to find that [[Costa Rica]] did not have to pay the [[United Kingdom]] debts incurred by the [[Federico Tinoco Granados]] regime.[http://digitalcommons.law.yale.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1336&context=yjil Odette Lienau, ''Who Is the “Sovereign” in Sovereign Debt?: Reinterpreting a Rule-of-Law Framework from the Early Twentieth Century''], 33 YALE J. INT’L L. 63 (2008). == Reception == Patricia Adams, executive director of Probe International, a [[Canada|Canadian]] environmental and public policy advocacy organization and author of ''Odious Debts: Loose Lending, Corruption, and the Third World's Environmental Legacy'', stated: "by giving creditors an incentive to lend only for purposes that are transparent and of public benefit, future tyrants will lose their ability to finance their armies, and thus the [[War on Terror|war on terror]] and the cause of world peace will be better served."{{cite book|author1=Patricia Adams|title=Odious Debts: Loose Lending, Corruption, and the Third World's Environmental Legacy|date=1991|isbn=978-1853831225|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-K3YAwAAQBAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s}} In a [[Cato Institute]] policy analysis, Adams suggested that debts incurred by [[Iraq]] during [[Saddam Hussein]]'s reign were odious because the money was spent on weapons, instruments of repression, and palaces.Patricia Adams, [http://www.cato.org/pubs/pas/pa-526es.html "Iraq's Odious Debt"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060103223442/http://www.cato.org//pubs/pas/pa-526es.html |date=2006-01-03 }}, Cato Institute A 2002 article by economists Seema Jayachandran and [[Michael Kremer]] renewed interest in this topic.{{cite news | author1= Michael Kremer |author2 = Seema Jayachandran |title = Odious Debt: When Dictators Borrow, Who Repays the Loan?| url= http://www.brookings.edu/research/articles/2003/03/spring-development-kremer |work = Brookings Institution |date=Spring 2003}} They propose that the idea can be used to create a new type of economic sanction to block further borrowing by [[dictators]].{{cite journal | author1 = Michael Kremer| author2= Seema Jayachandran|journal= [[Finance & Development]]|title=Odious Debt|date=June 2002|volume = 39| issue=2| url= http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/fandd/2002/06/kremer.htm | publisher =IMF}} Jayachandran proposed new recommendations in November 2010 at the 10th anniversary of the Jubilee movement at the [[Center for Global Development]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]http://www.cgdev.org/content/article/detail/1424565 Subsequently, the loan sanctions model has been adapted by the Centre for Global Developmentshttp://www.cgdev.org/working-group/prevention-odious-debt-working-group and has been the base for a number of further suggestions.{{cite journal | last = Schneider | first = Friedrich Benjamin | title = The International Convention on the Prevention of Odious Agreements: A Human Rights-Based Mechanism to Avoid Odious Debts | journal=Leiden Journal of International Law | volume = 28 | publisher=Cambridge University Press | year = 2015 | url = http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=9882300&fileId=S0922156515000291 |issue=3 |pages=557–578}} Some think the doctrine could aid [[international development]].[http://scholarship.law.duke.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1435&context=lcp Tom Ginsburg & Thomas S. Ulen, ''Odious Debt, Odious Credit, Economic Development, and Democratization''], 70 LAW & CONTEMP. PROBS. 115 (2007). Others think that the doctrine should allow even more kinds of debt to be canceled.[http://www.repository.law.indiana.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1010&context=facpub Christiana Ochoa, ''From Odious Debt to Odious Finance: Avoiding the Externalities of a Functional Odious Debt Doctrine''], 49 HARV. INT’L L.J. 109 (2008). ==Application== In December 2008, [[Ecuador]]ian President [[Rafael Correa]] attempted to default on Ecuador's [[national debt]], calling it illegitimate odious debt, because it was contracted by corrupt and despotic prior regimes.{{cite news|title=Ecuador defaults on foreign debt |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7780984.stm|work=BBC|date=13 December 2008}} He succeeded in reducing the price of the debt letters before continuing paying the debt.[http://therealnews.com/id/3622/April27,2009/%22Avenger+against+oligarchy%22+wins+in+Ecuador "'Avenger against oligarchy' wins in Ecuador"], ''[[The Real News]]'', 27 April 2009. After the overthrow of [[Haiti]]'s [[Jean-Claude Duvalier]] in 1986, there were calls to cancel Haiti's debt owed to multilateral institutions, calling it unjust odious debt, and Haiti could better use the funds for education, health care, and basic infrastructure.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070208224330/http://www.jubileeusa.org/jubilee.cgi?path=%2Ftake_action&page=haiti06.html Haiti Debt Action] As of February 2008, the Haiti Debt Cancellation Resolution had 66 co-sponsors in the [[U.S. House of Representatives]].[http://waters.house.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=169193 "Congresswoman Maxine Waters Introduces Legislation to Cancel Haiti’s Debt"] Several organizations in the United States issued [[action alert]]s around the Haiti Debt Cancellation Resolution, and a Congressional letter to the [[U.S. Treasury]],{{cite web|url=http://www.ijdh.org/articles/articles/article_recent_news_2-12-08.html |title=Institute for Justice & Democracy in Haiti |publisher=Ijdh.org |date=2008-02-12 |accessdate=2012-10-23}} including Jubilee USA, the [[Institute for Justice & Democracy in Haiti]] and Pax Christi USA. == See also == *[[Debt relief]] *[[Debt of developing countries]] *[[Jubilee USA Network]] *[[Haiti's external debt]] *[[Moral hazard]] *[[Sovereign debt]] *[[Sovereign default]] *[[Domestic Liability Dollarization]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} {{debt}} [[Category:Debt]] [[Category:International law]] [[Category:Legal doctrines and principles]]

{{Libertarianism sidebar |Schools}} '''Paleolibertarianism''' is a variety of [[libertarianism]] developed by [[anarcho-capitalism|anarcho-capitalist]] theorists [[Murray Rothbard]] and [[Llewellyn Rockwell, Jr.|Llewellyn Rockwell]] that combines [[cultural conservatism|conservative cultural values]] and social philosophy with a libertarian opposition to government intervention.<ref name=LR/>
==Tenets<!--'Beltway libertarianism' redirects here-->== According to Rockwell, the paleolibertarian movement hearkens back to such thinkers as "[[Ludwig von Mises]], [[Albert Jay Nock]], [[Garet Garrett]], and the entire interwar [[Old Right (United States)|Old Right]] that opposed the [[New Deal]] and favored the Old Republic"<ref name=KDC>[https://www.lewrockwell.com/lrc-blog/paleolibertarianism/ "Paleolibertarianism"] by Karen De Coster, ''LewRockwell.com'', December 2, 2003</ref> and distinguished themselves from "[[Neo-libertarianism|neo-libertarians]]" and from "Beltway Libertarianism, [[Left-Libertarianism]], and [[Lifestyle (sociology)|Lifestyle]] Libertarianism".<ref name=KDC/> ('''Beltway libertarianism'''<!--boldface per WP:R#PLA--> is a pejorative term used by [[hardline]] libertarians to describe libertarians who have gained traction in the [[Inside the Beltway|Beltway]], i.e. [[Washington, D.C.]])<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wearelibertarians.com/importance-beltway-libertarianism-disagree-tom-woods-lew-rockwell/|title=The Importance of Beltway Libertarianism|date=|website=wearelibertarians.com}}</ref> According to Rockwell, paleolibertarianism "made its peace with religion as the bedrock of liberty, property, and the [[natural order (philosophy)|natural order]]".
Paleolibertarianism developed in opposition to the social progressivism of mainstream libertarianism. In his essay "The Case for Paleo-Libertarianism", Rockwell charged mainstream libertarians with "hatred of [[Western culture]]".<ref name=LR/> He argued that "pornographic photography, 'free'-thinking, chaotic painting, atonal music, deconstructionist literature, Bauhaus architecture, and modernist films have nothing in common with the libertarian political agenda – no matter how much individual libertarians may revel in them".<ref name=LR/> Of paleolibertarians, he wrote "we obey, and we ought to obey, traditions of manners and taste".<ref name=LR/> After explaining why cultural conservatives could make a better argument for liberty to the middle classes, Rockwell predicted "in the new movement, libertarians who personify the present corruption will sink to their natural level, as will the Libertarian Party, which has been their diabolic pulpit".<ref name=LR>{{cite journal|last1=Rockwell|first1=Lew|title=The Case for Paleo-libertarianism|journal=[[Liberty (libertarian magazine)]]|issue=January 1990|pages=34–38|url=http://www.pericles.press/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/Liberty_Magazine.pdf}}</ref>
==Early history== In the essay "Right-Wing Populism: A Strategy for the Paleo Movement", Rothbard reflected on the ability of paleolibertarians to engage in an "outreach to [[redneck]]s" founded on social conservatism and radical libertarianism. He cited former [[Ku Klux Klan]] Grand Wizard [[David Duke]] and former U.S. Senator [[Joseph McCarthy]] as models for the new movement.<ref>Murray Rothbard. [http://rothbard.altervista.org/articles/right-wing-populism.pdf "Right-Wing Populism: A Strategy for the Paleo Movement"]. 1992.</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Sanchez|first1=Julian|last2=Weigel|first2=David|title=Who Wrote Ron Paul's Newsletters?|url=http://reason.com/archives/2008/01/16/who-wrote-ron-pauls-newsletter|publisher=Reason Foundation|quote=Rothbard pointed to David Duke and Joseph McCarthy as models for an "Outreach to the Rednecks," which would fashion a broad libertarian/paleoconservative coalition by targeting the disaffected working and middle classes}}</ref>
In the 1990s, a "[[paleoconservative]]-paleolibertarian alliance was forged", centred on the [[Rockford Institute|John Randolph Club]] founded by [[Traditionalist Catholic]] [[Thomas Fleming (political writer)|Thomas Fleming]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Martland|first1=Keir|title=Liberty from a Beginner:Selected Essays|date=2016|isbn=9781326524715|page=62|edition=Second}}</ref> Rockwell and Rothbard supported [[paleoconservatism|paleoconservative]] [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] candidate [[Pat Buchanan]] in the 1992 U.S. presidential election, and described Buchanan as the political leader of the "paleo" movement.<ref>{{cite book |last=Gottfried |first=Paul |authorlink=Paul Gottfried |title=The Conservative Movement |year=1993 |publisher=Twayne Publishers |isbn=0-8057-9723-8 |oclc=16804886 |pages=[https://books.google.com/books?ei=7–sfUZz6GqGA0AHz3YDABQ&id=4lTuAAAAMAAJ&dq=Fleming+Gottfried+The+Conservative+Movement&q=Rothbard#search_anchor 146]}}</ref> In 1992, Rothbard declared that "with [[Pat Buchanan]] as our leader, we shall break the clock of [[social democracy]]".<ref>Lee Edwards, [https://books.google.com/books?id=jn9mEDvqdZAC The Conservative Revolution: The Movement That Remade America], Simon and Schuster, 1999, [https://books.google.com/books?id=jn9mEDvqdZAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Conservative+Revolution:+The+Movement+That+Remade+America&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Zu0fUau3CqPA0QGHj4D4Bg&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Rothbard&f=false p. 329].</ref>
Three years later, he said Buchanan developed too much faith in [[economic planning]] and centralized state power, which eventually led paleolibertarians to withdraw their support for Buchanan.<ref name=Interview>Lew Rockwell, [http://archive.lewrockwell.com/rockwell/paleoism.html "What I Learned From Paleoism"], at ''LewRockwell.com'', May 2, 2002.</ref> In addition to Buchanan's "economic nationalism", [[Paul Gottfried]] later complained of a lack of funding, infighting, media hostility or blackout, and vilification as "racists" and "anti-Semites".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Martland|first1=Keir|title=Liberty from a Beginner:Selected Essays|date=2016|isbn=9781326524715|page=64|edition=Second}}</ref>
Rothbard died in 1995, while in 2007 Rockwell stated he no longer considered himself a "paleolibertarian" and was "happy with the term libertarian".<ref>[http://archive.lewrockwell.com/rockwell/liberal-post-interview.html "Do You Consider Yourself a Libertarian?"], Kenny Johnsson interviews Lew Rockwell for [http://liberalpost.wordpress.com/ ''The Liberal Post''], as posted on [http://lewrockwell.com LewRockwell.Com], May 25, 2007.</ref>
==Controversy== Political scientist and [[lesbian feminist]] activist [[Jean Hardisty]] describes paleolibertarianism as entailing "explicit racism, anti-Semitism, and sexism".<ref>Hardisty, Jean (1999). ''Mobilizing Resentment, Conservative Resurgence from the John Birch Society to the Promise Keepers''. Boston, MA: Beacon Press. pp. 165–67. Author holds a Ph.D. in Political Science from Northwestern University.</ref> She notes Rothbard's praise of ''[[The Bell Curve]]'', a controversial work which presents the intelligence of black people as statistically inferior to other races, and the ''Rothbard-Rockwell Report's'' publishing of an article, written by [[Samuel T. Francis|Sam Francis]], which asserted that "of the two major races in the United States today, only one possesses the capacity to create and sustain" suitable levels of civilization.
===Ron Paul newsletters=== {{main|Ron Paul newsletters}} The libertarian publication ''[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]]'' asserted that, "a half-dozen longtime libertarian activists—including some still close to [[Ron Paul]]—all named the same man as Paul's chief ghostwriter: Ludwig von Mises Institute founder Llewellyn Rockwell, Jr." Rockwell denied it.<ref name=":0">''[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]]'': Matt Welch, [http://reason.com/blog/2008/01/11/old-news-rehashed-for-over-a-d "Old News"? "Rehashed for Over a Decade"?], January 11, 2008 and [[Julian Sanchez (writer)|Sanchez, Julian]] and [[David Weigel|Weigel, David]], [http://www.reason.com/news/show/124426.html Who Wrote Ron Paul's Newsletters?], January 16, 2008. *Joe Conason, [http://www.salon.com/2010/05/21/racial/ Rand Paul The roots of Rand Paul’s civil rights resentment], ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]'', May 21, 2010. *David Weigel, [http://www.slate.com/blogs/weigel/2011/12/15/our_odd_ron_paul_moment_.html Our Odd Ron Paul "Moment"], ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', December 15, 2011. *Alex Massie, [http://blogs.spectator.co.uk/alex-massie/2011/12/ron-pauls-newsletter-problem/ Ron Paul's Newsletter Problem], ''[[The Spectator]]'', December 22, 2011.</ref>
==Revival== ===United States=== {{Libertarianism in the United States sidebar}} In 2012, former ''[[National Review]]'' writer [[John Derbyshire]] argued that "since Lew Rockwell joined La Raza" (referring to a LewRockwell.com's article with a soft open-borders advocacy)<ref>[http://www.vdare.com/articles/john-derbyshire-on-the-last-paleolibertarian "On Hans-Herman Hoppe – The Last Paleolibertarian"] ''VDare.com,'' 24 September 2012; Derbyshire was referring to the fact that the site LewRockwell.com published a soft open-borders position article at the time.</ref> [[Hans-Hermann Hoppe]] was the last real paleolibertarian standing. Yet paleolibertarianism had hardly disappeared from America, with Karen De Coster<ref>[http://karendecoster.com/about "About"] Karen De Coster</ref> and [[Justin Raimondo]] both continuing to use the term to describe themselves both during and after [[Ron Paul]]'s presidential campaigns.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NJUaj7IALMw "Ron Paul and the Prospects of Paleo-Libertarianism"] Justin Raimondo</ref>
In a move similar to his and Rothbard's support for Pat Buchanan, [[Lew Rockwell]] has been sympathetic to celebrity real estate mogul [[Donald Trump]]'s [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|2016 presidential campaign]], particularly for his stance on Mexican immigration,<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BQ_I3rLKWWs "The Trump Phenomenon"] The Tom Woods Show</ref> along with [[Justin Raimondo]], who voted for Trump on the basis of his foreign policy.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://radio.foxnews.com/2016/12/29/do-you-have-trump-derangement-syndrome/# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-12-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161231075826/http://radio.foxnews.com/2016/12/29/do-you-have-trump-derangement-syndrome/# |archive-date=2016-12-31 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> [[Austrian School]] anarcho-capitalist economist [[Walter Block]], in a 2016 preelection debate with ''Reason.com'' editor [[Nick Gillespie]], advised libertarians living in battleground states to support Trump rather than cast their votes for [[Libertarian Party of the United States|Libertarian Party]] nominee [[Gary Johnson]], citing critical foreign policy differences between the Republican and Democratic frontrunners.
Jeff Deist, President of the [[Ludwig von Mises Institute]], a [[right-libertarianism|right-libertarian]] think tank for promoting Rothbardian anarcho-capitalism and the Austrian School of economics, said of the [[Alt-right]] that he found their writings "interesting...and somewhat refreshing".<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NxkV-A5dBZc "Alt-Right vs. Socialist Left"] Mises Institute</ref> In 2017, Deist concluded a speech at the Mises Institute titled 'For a New Libertarian' with the words, "In other words, blood and soil and God and nation still matter to people. Libertarians ignore this at the risk of irrelevance."<ref>https://mises.org/blog/new-libertarian</ref> This led to criticism from 'Bleeding Heart Libertarian' Steve Horwitz. Horwitz argued that libertarianism was not about family, religion, culture, and civil society, but instead "liberal tolerance, universalism, and cosmopolitanism, putting the freedom and harmony of all people ahead of the supposed interests of any parochial sub-group, and especially ones defined by the artificial boundaries of nation-states and their subsets."<ref>http://bleedingheartlibertarians.com/2017/08/rhetoric-libertarians-unfortunate-appeal-alt-right/</ref>
Popular political and cultural blog ''[[The_Right_Stuff_(blog)|The Right Stuff]]'' also exhibits features of paleolibertarianism.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://therightstuff.biz/about-us/|website=The Right Stuff.biz|accessdate=19 February 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160830061426/http://therightstuff.biz/about-us/|archivedate=30 August 2016|df=}}</ref> One post has criticised the mainstream right in the following terms, "While they lost or ignore topics like race, nativism and the culture war, they have an obsession with neoliberal economics and neocon geopolitics."<ref>{{cite web|title=Why the Weak Right is Wrong|url=http://therightstuff.biz/2015/07/24/why-the-weak-right-is-dead-wrong/|website=The Right Stuff.biz|accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref> They have also been largely supportive of Rockwell, yet have criticised his "move away from inflammatory newsletters".<ref>{{cite web|title=Après Paul, Le Déluge|url=http://therightstuff.biz/2013/02/28/apres-paul-le-deluge/|website=The Right Stuff.biz|accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref>
===Canada=== Controversial [[voluntaryism|voluntaryist]] blogger and podcaster [[Stefan Molyneux]] circa 2014 started to become more [[cultural conservatism|culturally conservative]] than he had been previously. He has released podcasts of his ''Freedomain Radio'' show addressing topics such as [[Western culture]],<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BT1X_ZHWqDM "The Impending Collapse of Western Civilisation"] Stefan Molyneux</ref> [[immigration]],<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QV7JILRugOg "The Truth About Immigration"] Stefan Molyneux</ref> and group differences in cognitive ability.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4x-tYmyJSVo "IQ and Immigration"] Stefan Molyneux</ref> He, like [[Lew Rockwell|Rockwell]], has supported [[Donald Trump]] for the presidency of the [[United States]].<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gw8c2Cq-vpg "The Untruth About Donald Trump"] Stefan Molyneux</ref>
[[Property and Freedom Society]] member Christian Robitaille has argued for an alliance of libertarians and [[traditionalist conservatism|traditionalists]] in [[Quebec]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Robitaille|first1=Christian|title=Pourquoi libertariens et traditionalistes sont des alliés naturels|url=https://www.contrepoints.org/2016/01/25/236587-pourquoi-libertariens-et-traditionalistes-sont-des-allies-naturels|website=Contrepoints|accessdate=8 March 2016}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== Since late 2013, [[High Tory]] organisation the [[Western Goals Institute#Traditional Britain Group|Traditional Britain Group]] has been influenced by paleolibertarian ideas. In March 2014, it hosted a seminar including a track led by Dr Andrew Linley, 'Politics: destroyer of natural order'.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Linley|first1=Andrew|title=Politics: Destroyer of Natural Order|url=http://traditionalbritain.org/blog/traditional-britain-seminars-2014-andrew-linley-politics-destroyer-natural-order/|website=Traditional Britain Group|accessdate=27 January 2016|date=March 2014}}</ref> The Vice President of the Traditional Britain Group, Professor John Kersey, describes himself as a 'radical traditionalist and paleolibertarian'.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kersey|first1=John|title=Preserving the substance of a nation|url=http://traditionalbritain.org/blog/traditional-britain-conference-preserving-substance-nation-john-kersey/|website=Traditional Britain Group|accessdate=27 January 2016|date=October 2013}}</ref> In October 2014, former [[UKIP]] MEP and Mises UK President [[Godfrey Bloom]] gave a speech to the annual conference of Traditional Britain entitled "Why Traditionalism and Libertarianism are Not Incompatible".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bloom|first1=Godfrey|title=Why Traditionalism and Libertarianism are not incompatible|url=http://traditionalbritain.org/blog/godfrey-bloom-why-traditionalism-and-libertarianism-are-not-incompatible/|website=Traditional Britain|accessdate=27 January 2016}}</ref>
The former Director of the [[Libertarian Alliance]], [[Sean Gabb]], is a close friend of Hans-Hermann Hoppe, attending his [[Property and Freedom Society]] conferences every year in [[Bodrum]]. Gabb is a conservative in some respects and a critic of mass-immigration.<ref>{{cite web|title=Must Libertarians Believe in Open Borders?|url=https://misesuk.org/2015/08/12/must-libertarians-believe-in-open-borders/|website=Mises UK|accessdate=9 July 2017}}</ref> Gabb has addressed Traditional Britain Group conferences in efforts at classical liberal outreach to traditionalists.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gabb|first1=Sean|title=In Defence of English Civilisation|url=http://traditionalbritain.org/blog/defence-english-civilization-sean-gabb-conference-talk/|website=Traditional Britain Group|accessdate=27 January 2016|date=2012}}</ref> Gabb's successor, Keir Martland, has written favourably about the prospects for a new "paleo-alliance", arguing that "a conservative society cannot exist under an oppressive state just as much as a libertarian society cannot exist in a cultural and moral vacuum".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Martland|first1=Keir|title=Paleoism and the Traditional Britain Group|url=http://www.ncc-1776.org/tle2014/tle755-20140126-03.html|website=The Libertarian Enterprise|accessdate=27 January 2016|date=January 26, 2014}}</ref> In an essay 'On Left and Right, Libertarianism, and The Donald', Martland, like Jeff Deist, is sympathetic to the nationalism of Donald Trump: "When compared with rule by a socialist mob or rule by a hostile oligarchy of globalists, neither giving a damn about the Nation but only about plunder, nationalism comes off comparatively very well indeed."<ref>https://misesuk.org/2016/09/20/on-left-and-right-libertarianism-and-the-donald/</ref>

'''Pat Lee Lauderdale''' (born Hobart, Oklahoma, U.S.A. October 19, 1944) is an American professor in the School of Justice and Social Inquiry at [[Arizona State University]]. He received his doctorate in the [[sociology of law]] from [[Stanford University]]. In 2008, he was appointed a visiting scholar at the Center for Comparative Studies in Race and Ethnicity at Stanford University. His teaching and research interests include indigenous jurisprudence, [[racialization]], diversity, global indigenous struggles, law and the social science, and [[Terrorism|international terrorism]]. In the 1980s he helped create the [[Herbert Blumer]] Institute in [[Costa Rica]] with the goal of discovering and describing alternatives to violence and [[criminal law]]. He also is known internationally for his research on the relationship between social deviance, law and diversity, and is a former editor of the ''International Studies Quarterly''.<ref>http://muse.jhu.edu/login?uri=/journals/wicazo_sa_review/v021/21.1gray.html</ref><ref>http://sjsi.clas.asu.edu/</ref><ref>https://sec.was.asu.edu/directory/person/10857</ref>
His book ''Law and Society'' (with James Inverarity and Barry Feld) has been translated into Japanese. His related research has been published in Spanish, German, and Italian (including the Calabrian dialect).
He is the former Director of the University-wide Ph.D./J.D. program in Justice Studies, Law, and the [[Social sciences|Social Sciences]]. Before coming to ASU in 1981, Dr. Lauderdale was an [[Professor|Associate Professor]] of Sociology and Law at the University of Minnesota. He had been a Visiting Scholar at the University of California, [[Santa Cruz, California|Santa Cruz]]. He has received Fulbright Research Fellowships to Costa Rica and Austria. He also has been a Visiting Scholar and Professor at the University of Lecci, Italy, the University of Austria, and Stanford University. In 2007, he received an invitation to be a Fulbright Senior Specialist for a research project on "Indigenous peoples, minorities and globalization," Department of Sociology and UNISA Press, [[University of South Africa]]. He was a National President of [[Phi Theta Kappa]] [[Honor society|Honorary Society]] and a [[Woodrow Wilson]] Scholar.

[[Freedom Union (Poland)|Freedom Union]] | otherparty = [[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe|ALDE]] | spouse = Aleksandra Piskorska | profession = [[Historian]] | religion = | signature = | footnotes = }}'''Paweł Bartłomiej Piskorski''' (born February 25, 1968 in [[Warsaw]]) is a former Polish politician. He was [[Mayor of Warsaw]] from 30 March 1999 to 14 January 2002. In 1997 he was elected to the [[Sejm]] from the [[Freedom Union (Poland)|Freedom Union]] electoral list, and in 2001, after participating in a secession from that party, he successfully ran under the [[Civic Platform]] banner. In 2004 he was the Secretary General of Civic Platform.''[[The Guardian]]'', 11 April 2004, [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2004/apr/11/eu.features In from the cold] He has been elected Member of the [[European Parliament]] in 2004. April 26, 2006 excluded from the Civic Platform{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}}. Since February 2009 he has been the chairman of the [[Democratic Party (Poland)|Democratic Party]].Newsweek.pl, 21 February 2009, [http://www.newsweek.pl/artykuly/sekcje/polska/pawel-piskorski-nowym-szefem-sd,36713,1 Paweł Piskorski nowym szefem SD] ==Alleged corruption== In April 2006 Polish newspaper "Dziennik" informed about the purchased transaction performed in 2005 by Pawel Piskorski with his wife of more than 320 hectares of land for afforestation. The total cost of the purchase amounted to 1.25 million zł. According to the journalist of this newspaper, this amount exceeded the value of assets declared by an MEP in a financial statement for that year.Bankier.pl,April 2006, [http://www.bankier.pl/wiadomosc/Skad-Piskorski-mial-pieniadze-na-zakup-lasu-1426101.html Where did Piskorski had the money to purchase the forest from?] Pawel Piskorski had explained that the money came from the sale of housing, credit, savings and current income him and his wife. That declaration had not been officially challenged by any public authority. Nevertheless, Piskorski's reputation has been irrecoverably damaged. The day after the publication of the national board of the PO decided about his exclusion from the party, which was followed on May 17 be removal of all his ten collaborators, among others, Piotr Fogler. The official reason stated was damages to the image of the Civic Platform.wp.pl, April 2006,[http://wiadomosci.wp.pl/kat,1342,wid,8288689,wiadomosc.html?ticaid=16d71, Pawel Piskorski removed from Civic Platform ] In January 2009 Piotr Piskorski joined the Democratic Party, thus becoming the only MEP of the party, as well as declaring his intention to run for the position of chairman. This position is obtained at an extraordinary congress Democratic Party, held on February 21 the same year. However, his nomination was followed by the publication of his statements given to National Revenue Service agency to explain sources of his income. He tried to explain that he earned money by persistent winnings at the casino and by art trading. The public opinion has taken these clarifications with disbelief, which torpedoed election campaign of the Democratic Party. In January 2010, introduced prosecutor charged him with the use of a forged document (contract with an antique dealer) in tax proceedings. Pawel Piskorski pleaded not guilty to committing this act. Piskorski is listed in the [[Panama Papers]] as a beneficiary or shareholder in an [[offshore company]].{{Cite news|url=https://panamapapers.icij.org/the_power_players/|title=The Power Players|access-date=2017-02-04}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100203114530/http://www.piskorski.pl/www/ official website] (in Polish) {{Presidents of Warsaw}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Piskorski, Pawel}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Politicians from Warsaw]] [[Category:Presidents of Warsaw]] [[Category:Liberal Democratic Congress politicians]] [[Category:Freedom Union (Poland) politicians]] [[Category:Civic Platform politicians]] [[Category:Alliance of Democrats (Poland) politicians]] [[Category:Members of the Polish Sejm 1991–93]] [[Category:Members of the Polish Sejm 1997–2001]] [[Category:Members of the Polish Sejm 2001–05]] [[Category:Civic Platform MEPs]] [[Category:MEPs for Poland 2004–09]] [[Category:Political corruption]] [[Category:Corruption in Poland]] [[Category:People named in the Panama Papers]]

{{Prerogative writs}} A '''peremptory writ of mandamus''' (also '''peremptory writ of mandate''' or simply '''peremptory mandamus''') is an absolute and unqualified [[writ]] (a formal written command) to the [[defendant]] to do the act in question. It is issued when the defendant [[default (law)|defaults]] on, or fails to show sufficient [[cause]] in answer to, an alternative [[mandamus]]. It is one of the three types of a [[mandamus]].
A more exact definition of a peremptory writ of mandate is "a final order of a court to any governmental body, government official or a lower court to perform an act the court finds is an official duty required by law." <ref name="Legal Dictionary">[http://legal-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/peremptory+writ+of+mandate Legal Dictionary]</ref> <ref name="Law Dictionary">[http://dictionary.law.com/default2.asp?selected=1502&bold=%7C%7C%7C%7C Law Dictionary]</ref>
==Distinguishing from other kinds of mandamus== A peremptory writ of mandate "is distinguished from an alternative writ of mandate (mandamus), which orders the governmental agency, court or officials to obey the order or show cause at a hearing why it should not." <ref name="Legal Dictionary"/> <ref name="Law Dictionary"/>
This may also be distinguished from a [[continuing mandamus]], which asks for an officer or other authority to perform its tasks expeditiously for an unstipulated period of time for preventing miscarriage of justice.<ref>See ''Vineet Narain v. Union of India'', AIR 1996 SC 3386.</ref>
"The usual practice is for anyone desiring such an order is to file a petition for the alternative writ. If the officials do not comply with the order and fail to convince the court that the writ of mandate should not be issued, then the court will issue the peremptory writ. In some emergency situations or when there is no conceivable reason for the government not to follow the law, then the peremptory writ will be issued after a notice of hearing without the alternative writ." <ref name="Legal Dictionary"/> <ref name="Law Dictionary"/>
In some [[jurisdiction]]s or [[court system]]s, all types or kinds of writs are bunched together under a single procedural framework. In [[New York (state)|New York]] [[Civil procedure|civil practice]], any writ is titled a '''proceeding against (a) body or officer'''. <ref>N.Y. Civil Practice Law & Rules (CPLR) Article 78, [on the web at http://www.assembly.state.ny.us/leg/ and go to CVP].</ref>
